ProviderPreviewInfo.ProviderName
Used when contacting or addressing the responsible person. Because this will be the principle means of identifying the responsible person, it is mandatory.

Describes a person (other than a health-care provider or patient) who is providing information and making decision on behalf of the patient, in relation to the delivery of healthcare for the patient. E.g. Patient's mother.
Important for tracking source of information for decision making and other actions taken on behalf of a patient.
A unique identifier for the responsible person.

Allows a person to be uniquely referred to.
A coded value indicating how the responsible person is related to the person for whom they have accepted responsibility.
May be important for understanding the authority to perform certain actions. E.g. A 'friend' may not be able to make consent decisions, but may be able to pick up dispenses.
The mail and/or physical address associated with a responsible person.

Used to contact the responsible person.
A person who is receiving or may receive healthcare services and has personal attributes (e.g. name, birth date). .

Information used to identify the patient and to support clinical decisions. This information applies to the person in the context of the associated action only, and should be stored separately. I.e. the address/phone/email only apply to the current prescription/dispense/lab order etc.

Unique identifier assigned to a person by Federal, Provincial and Territorial jurisdiction for the purposes of uniquely identifying the person within the EHR.

The EHR will define which identifier to use within a jurisdiction.

Unique identifier assigned to a person by Federal, Provincial and Territorial jurisdiction for the purposes of uniquely identifying the person within the EHR.

The EHR will define which identifier to use within a jurisdiction.

Allows a patient to be referred to unambiguously. Because this is the principal mechanism for identifying humans, the attribute is mandatory. If an identifier is not known, it should be looked up using the 'client registry' capabilities of the EHR application.
The name by which the patient is known and which apply to a particular clinical action that has been reported or recorded.

Used, with other patient identity attributes, to confirm patient identity, as well as when addressing the patient. Element is mandatory because the patient's name is necessary for positive identification of the patient in the jurisdictional client registry.
Indicates the gender (sex) of the patient. Complex genetic genders are handled as observations if they are considered relevant.

Used to confirm patient identity. May affect dosing or therapy appropriateness.

Element is mandatory because the patient's gender is necessary for positive identification of the patient in the jurisdictional client registry.

Used to confirm patient identity. May affect dosing or therapy appropriateness.

Element is mandatory because the patient's gender is necessary for positive identification of the patient in the jurisdictional client registry.
Indicates the date on which the patient was born.

Used to confirm patient identity.

May also influence dosage and therapy appropriateness.

Element is mandatory because the patient's birth date is necessary for positive identification of the patient in the jurisdictional client registry.

Used to confirm patient identity.

May also influence dosage and therapy appropriateness.

Element is mandatory because the patient's birth date is necessary for positive identification of the patient in the jurisdictional client registry.

Used to confirm patient identity.

May also influence dosage and therapy appropriateness.

Element is mandatory because the patient's birth date is necessary for positive identification of the patient in the jurisdictional client registry.
A person who is receiving or may receive healthcare services and has personal attributes (e.g. name, birth date). .

Information used to identify the patient and to support clinical decisions. This information applies to the person in the context of the associated action only, and should be stored separately. I.e. the address/phone/email only apply to the current prescription/dispense/lab order etc.

Unique identifier assigned to a person by Federal, Provincial and Territorial jurisdiction for the purposes of uniquely identifying the person within the EHR.

The EHR will define which identifier to use within a jurisdiction.

Unique identifier assigned to a person by Federal, Provincial and Territorial jurisdiction for the purposes of uniquely identifying the person within the EHR.

The EHR will define which identifier to use within a jurisdiction.

Person.PHN (Extension)

Allows a patient to be referred to unambiguously. Because this is the principal mechanism for identifying humans, the attribute is mandatory. If an identifier is not known, it should be looked up using the 'client registry' capabilities of the EHR application.

Physical address for the patient where they may be visited or found for the purposes of this particular action. Generally only specified when different from the addresses stored on the client registry. E.g. address on a prescription issued when a patient is temporary staying away from home.

Can be used to record a temporary address used for the purposes of this prescription.

Not intended for use to confirm patient identity.

Telephone, fax or e-mail addresses intended as the principal means of contact for the patient with regard to the current action. E.g. the phone number to reach the patient at regarding the results of an ordered test.

On a prescription, this enables the communication of patient contact information to the dispenser for the specific prescription. This can be a phone/fax number and/or email address

Used, with other patient identity attributes, to confirm patient identity, as well as when addressing the patient. For animals, name is the primary identifier, and is therefore mandatory.
The mail and/or physical address associated with the owner or contact person for the animal.
Used to contact the owner or contact person
The phone number(s) and email address(s) by which the owner may be contacted.
Used to contact the owner or contact person
Describes a person who is to be contacted regarding the delivery of healthcare to the animal.
Important for tracking responsibility for decision making and other actions taken on behalf of an animal patient.
The name by which the owner person is known
Used when contacting or addressing the owner person. Because this will be the principle means of identifying the owner person, it is mandatory.
An animal that is receiving or may receive healthcare services.
Used when animal services are attached to a human patient record. E.g. narcotics prescribed for a pet may be attached to the owner's record for monitoring of abuse.
Describes a healthcare provider involved in the delivery of healthcare services. Encompasses both professional and non-professional members.

Important for tracking responsibility for healthcare events, as well as for identifying appropriate individuals to contact for further information or follow-up.

While an important piece of identifying information, not all providers will have identifiers, thus this attribute is only 'populated'.

Important for tracking responsibility for healthcare events, as well as for identifying appropriate individuals to contact for further information or follow-up.

While an important piece of identifying information, not all providers will have identifiers, thus this attribute is only 'populated'.
A unique identifier for a provider (e.g. the Prescriber on a new prescription).

ProviderRegistrationjurisdiction (part of Extension)
Allows a provider to be uniquely referred to but will not always be known and is therefore 'populated'.
A coded value indicating the professional category of a provider. This is usually the discipline of the provider (e.g. physician, pharmacist, dentist, etc).
Necessary for ascertaining providers' ability/competence in providing different types of health services.
A legal permission to provide healthcare of a particular type in a particular jurisdiction.
Important to evaluating permissions.
The identifier of a professional license issued to the provider by a licensing body.

License Number

Allows providers to verify/ascertain authority for clinical services.
If a provider possesses multiple licenses, this is the license that applies to the current action.
The name by which the provider is known (e.g. the Prescriber on a new prescription).

Used when contacting the provider. Also used by others to recognize a provider and then evaluate the information provided by a particular provider. This is the one piece of provider information which should always be known and is therefore mandatory.
An identification of a system/application that can initiate an event to change the status of an object.
Allows an application to be uniquely identified.
Unique identifier of an application or a system.

Facility.name
Used for human communication. The name of the application must be known and is therefore marked as 'mandatory'.

This is a list of comments made about the record by providers. Information captured here includes the provider making the comments; and excludes information that would render the record invalid. This information will only be seen when another provider reviews the record. Urgent or targeted messages should be sent using a different mechanism (e.g. phone).

Public Health requires all clinical notes to be 'verified' by a responsible party if not created by physician in charge. This model conveys the correct semantics, but is inconsistent with other uses of "author" participation in POIZ models. Any changes here will have to be reconciled with other projects using this same cmet.
Allows various Providers to attach comments to an existing record, and thus improving cross-provider communications.
Free text comments. Additional textual iinformation entered about an object.
Allows a provider to attach comments to objects for communication. This attribute is mandatory because there's no point in having a note class unless there's actually content in the note.
A coded value denoting the language in which the note is written.

Allows providers to write notes in the language of their choice.

This attribute is marked as 'populated' because the language of the note must always be known/available or a null flavor must be specified.

Allows providers to write notes in the language of their choice.

This attribute is marked as 'populated' because the language of the note must always be known/available or a null flavor must be specified.
Identifies the provider responsible for the content of the note.

Possible RIM issue: the use of author participation in this model is inconsistent with author participations used in other models, e.g author participation in Immunization event model (POIZ_MT030050CA).
Allows tracking of who made what comment. This attribute is marked as 'mandatory' because the provider posting a comment must always be known.
The date and time at which the note was posted.

Identifies timing of the annotation for sorting and for audit purposes.

This attribute is mandatory because the time of creation of the annotation will always be known.

Identifies timing of the annotation for sorting and for audit purposes.

This attribute is mandatory because the time of creation of the annotation will always be known.
A catalog of devices (manufactured material) from which devices may be selected for prescribing/dispensing.
A_BillablePharmacyDispense
Provides a list of devices available for prescribing/dispensing.
An identifier for a type of device.

Used to ensure clear communication by uniquely identifying a particular device product when prescribing or dispensing. This attribute is only marked as 'populated' because some devices will not have codes associated with them.
The name assigned to a type of device.

Names are used for human reference communication, to allow selection from dropdowns and for local searching. If a code is available, the name acts as a cross-check. If the code is not available the name acts as the primary identifier. The attribute is therefore mandatory.
First occurrence is preferred for display.

A free form textual description of a device and its characteristics (e.g. size, shape, etc.). This is used when additional information must be conveyed that is not apparent by just specifying code and name.
Allows description of characteristics of the device not necessarily conveyed by the code or name.
Information about how the device is packaged.
May influence prescribing quantities.
The quantity of devices contained in the package given or to be given to the patient.

Sometimes ordering and dispensing is by package rather than individual units, and package is important in calculating total amount supplied.

Attribute is marked as "mandatory" to ensure that quantity in a package is always known.

Sometimes ordering and dispensing is by package rather than individual units, and package is important in calculating total amount supplied.

Attribute is marked as "mandatory" to ensure that quantity in a package is always known.
A medical device product intended to be supplied and/or used by a patient. Encompasses supplies, aids, etc.
A_BillablePharmacyDispense
Allows devices to be clearly described and referenced. Also allows searching for and examining information about devices that can be or are being used by a patient.
Describes the container in which a device can be or should be provided to the patient.

Used for informing dispenser of the need and authorization to dispense device in a clinically approved container. Aids patients in adhering to usage instructions. May also influence the quantity prescribed.

The empty class is mandatory for HL7 alignment and modeling reasons.

Used for informing dispenser of the need and authorization to dispense device in a clinically approved container. Aids patients in adhering to usage instructions. May also influence the quantity prescribed.

The empty class is mandatory for HL7 alignment and modeling reasons.
Information about how the dispensed drug is or should be contained
A_BillablePharmacyDispense
May influence prescribing quantities, and also allows conveying instructions with respect to special packaging such as compliance packaging.
The quantity of the medication dosage form contained in the package given or to be given to the patient.

ZDP.10.2.2

ZDP.9.2.2

ZDP.10.2.2

ZDP.9.2.2
Sometimes ordering and dispensing is by package rather than individual units, and package is important in calculating total amount supplied.
Identification of which ingredients are contained (or are not contained) in a drug, along with their respective quantities.

Useful to providers in deciding appropriate use instruction (dosage specification) for patients. Also important in checking for potential adverse reactions to non-active ingredients. For compounds, allows contraindication checking against ingredients of custom compounds.
An indication that a drug does not contain the specified ingredient (active or inactive).

Useful for filtering searches. Allows providers to search for drugs not containing a specific active ingredients or excipients. E.g. lactose-free, gluten-free, etc.

The attribute is 'mandatory' because the distinction between "does/must contain" and "does/must not contain" is essential.

Useful for filtering searches. Allows providers to search for drugs not containing a specific active ingredients or excipients. E.g. lactose-free, gluten-free, etc.

The attribute is 'mandatory' because the distinction between "does/must contain" and "does/must not contain" is essential.
The quantity of the ingredient in a drug. This is represented/measured in various forms/units including: mg, mg/vol, %, etc.

Essential for evaluating appropriate dosage based on strength, as well as for creating custom compounds with proper composition.

A pharmaceutical product intended to be supplied and/or administered to a patient. Encompasses manufactured drug products, generic classifications, prescription medications, over-the-counter medications and recreational drugs.
A_BillablePharmacyDispense
Allows drugs to be clearly described and referenced. Also allows searching for and examining information about medications that can be or are being used by a patient.

A catalog of drugs (manufactured material) from which drugs may be selected for prescribing/dispensing. This includes: TC - Therapeutic Class; GD - Generic Drug; GF - Generic Formulation; MD - Manufactured Drug; and CMP - Compound
A_BillablePharmacyDispense
Provides a list of drugs available for prescribing/dispensing.

An identifier for a type of drug. Depending on where the drug is being referenced, the drug may be identified at different levels of abstraction. E.g. Manufactured drug (including vaccines), generic formulation, generic, therapeutic class, etc.

RXA.5

A_BillablePharmacyDispense

Used to ensure clear communication by uniquely identifying a particular drug product when prescribing or dispensing. This attribute is only marked as 'populated' because some custom compounds will not have unique identifiers Datatype has been retained as CE (Translatable Code) to support translation between multiple code sets for drugs (e.g. DIN, GTIN, UPC).
The name assigned to a drug.

Names are used for human reference communication, to allow selection from dropdowns and for local searching. If a code is available, the name acts as a cross-check. If the code is not available the name acts as the primary identifier. The attribute is therefore mandatory.
First occurrence is preferred for display.
A free form textual description of a drug. This usually is only populated for custom compounds, providing instructions on the composition and creation of the compound.

Dosage Form

Dosage Form
Provides a constrained vocabulary for describing dose forms. The form of the drug influences how it can be used by the patient.
Must be recorded if the Drug Id does not specify the Drug Form.
Describes the container in which a drug product can be or should be provided to the patient.
A_BillablePharmacyDispense
Aids patients in adhering to administration instructions (e.g. snap caps). May also influence the quantity prescribed.
A coded value denoting a specific kind of a container. Used to identify a requirement for a particular type of compliance packaging
Many insurance plans require that a prescriber specifically authorize the use of compliance packaging before it will be covered by the plan.
A list of drugs, chemicals or excipients that may or may not be present in a manufactured drug or a custom compound.
Important for expressing strength of active ingredients within a drug product, for expressing compound recipes, and for identifying potential causes for adverse reactions.
The unique identifier for the drug or chemical.

Allows un-ambiguous identification of the ingredients of a drug for performing various alert checking.

Also allows for the identification of antigens as class of ingredients in a vaccine.

Allows un-ambiguous identification of the ingredients of a drug for performing various alert checking.

Also allows for the identification of antigens as class of ingredients in a vaccine.
The name of the contained drug or chemical.
CompoundIngredient.IngredientDrug.drugProductName
Used for communication between and display to providers.
Information about how the dispensed drug is or should be contained
A_BillablePharmacyDispense
May influence prescribing quantities, and also allows conveying instructions with respect to special packaging such as compliance packaging.
The quantity of the medication dosage form contained in the package given or to be given to the patient.

ZDP.10.2.2

ZDP.9.2.2

ZDP.10.2.2

ZDP.9.2.2
Sometimes ordering and dispensing is by package rather than individual units, and package is important in calculating total amount supplied.
Identification of which ingredients are contained (or are not contained) in a drug, along with their respective quantities.

Useful to providers in deciding appropriate use instruction (dosage specification) for patients. Also important in checking for potential adverse reactions to non-active ingredients. For compounds, allows contraindication checking against ingredients of custom compounds.
An indication that a drug does not contain the specified ingredient (active or inactive).

Useful for filtering searches. Allows providers to search for drugs not containing a specific active ingredients or excipients. E.g. lactose-free, gluten-free, etc.

The attribute is 'populated' because the distinction between "does/must contain" and "does/must not contain" is essential, however in some circumstances it is necessary to say "may contain".

Useful for filtering searches. Allows providers to search for drugs not containing a specific active ingredients or excipients. E.g. lactose-free, gluten-free, etc.

The attribute is 'populated' because the distinction between "does/must contain" and "does/must not contain" is essential, however in some circumstances it is necessary to say "may contain".
The quantity of the ingredient in a drug. This is represented/measured in various forms/units including: mg, mg/vol, %, etc.

Compound.451-EG (unit)
Essential for evaluating appropriate dosage based on strength, as well as for creating custom compounds with proper composition.
Associates a drug product with the organization responsible for producing it.
May be important for tracing adverse events and for performing drug searches.
Identity of the organization that manufactured the drug product.
Useful in distinguishing and grouping drug products
An identifier denoting a specific drug manufacturer.
Allows sending of identifiers in place of manufacturer name. May be used in drug search where specific manufacturer is a criterion.
The name of the drug manufacturer.

Used for reporting.

The attribute is marked as "mandatory" because there will always be a name for an organization.

Used for reporting.

The attribute is marked as "mandatory" because there will always be a name for an organization.

A pharmaceutical product intended to be supplied and/or administered to a patient. Encompasses manufactured drug products, generic classifications, prescription medications, over-the-counter medications and recreational drugs.
A_BillablePharmacyDispense
Allows drugs to be clearly described and referenced. Also allows searching for and examining information about medications that can be or are being used by a patient.

A catalog of drugs (manufactured material) from which drugs may be selected for prescribing/dispensing. This includes: TC - Therapeutic Class; GD - Generic Drug; GF - Generic Formulation; MD - Manufactured Drug; and CMP - Compound
A_BillablePharmacyDispense
Provides a list of drugs available for prescribing/dispensing.

An identifier for a type of drug. Depending on where the drug is being referenced, the drug may be identified at different levels of abstraction. E.g. Manufactured drug (including vaccines), generic formulation, generic, therapeutic class, etc.

A_BillablePharmacyDispense

Used to ensure clear communication by uniquely identifying a particular drug product when prescribing or dispensing. This attribute is only marked as 'populated' because some custom compounds will not have unique identifiers Datatype has been retained as CE (Translatable Code) to support translation between multiple code sets for drugs (e.g. DIN, GTIN, UPC).

Names are used for human reference communication, to allow selection from dropdowns and for local searching. If a code is available, the name acts as a cross-check. If the code is not available the name acts as the primary identifier. The attribute is therefore mandatory.
First occurrence is preferred for display.
A free form textual description of a drug. This usually is only populated for custom compounds, providing instructions on the composition and creation of the compound.

Compound.450-EF

A_BillablePharmacyDispense

Dosage Form

Dosage Form
Provides a constrained vocabulary for describing dose forms. The form of the drug influences how it can be used by the patient.
Must be recorded if the Drug Id does not specify the Drug Form.
Describes the container in which a drug product can be or should be provided to the patient.
A_BillablePharmacyDispense
Aids patients in adhering to administration instructions (e.g. snap caps). May also influence the quantity prescribed.
A coded value denoting a specific kind of a container. Used to identify a requirement for a particular type of compliance packaging
Many insurance plans require that a prescriber specifically authorize the use of compliance packaging before it will be covered by the plan.
A list of drugs, chemicals or excipients that may or may not be present in a manufactured drug or a custom compound.
Important for expressing strength of active ingredients within a drug product, for expressing compound recipes, and for identifying potential causes for adverse reactions.
The unique identifier for the drug or chemical.

Allows un-ambiguous identification of the ingredients of a drug for performing various alert checking.

Also allows for the identification of antigens as class of ingredients in a vaccine.

Allows un-ambiguous identification of the ingredients of a drug for performing various alert checking.

Also allows for the identification of antigens as class of ingredients in a vaccine.
The name of the contained drug or chemical.
CompoundIngredient.IngredientDrug.drugProductName
Used for communication between and display to providers.
Information about how the dispensed drug is or should be contained
A_BillablePharmacyDispense
May influence prescribing quantities, and also allows conveying instructions with respect to special packaging such as compliance packaging.
The quantity of the medication dosage form contained in the package given or to be given to the patient.

ZDP.10.2.2

ZDP.9.2.2

ZDP.10.2.2

ZDP.9.2.2
Sometimes ordering and dispensing is by package rather than individual units, and package is important in calculating total amount supplied.
Identification of which ingredients are contained (or are not contained) in a drug, along with their respective quantities.

Useful to providers in deciding appropriate use instruction (dosage specification) for patients. Also important in checking for potential adverse reactions to non-active ingredients. For compounds, allows contraindication checking against ingredients of custom compounds.
An indication that a drug does not contain the specified ingredient (active or inactive).

Useful for filtering searches. Allows providers to search for drugs not containing a specific active ingredients or excipients. E.g. lactose-free, gluten-free, etc.

The attribute is 'mandatory' because the distinction between "does/must contain" and "does/must not contain" is essential.

Useful for filtering searches. Allows providers to search for drugs not containing a specific active ingredients or excipients. E.g. lactose-free, gluten-free, etc.

The attribute is 'mandatory' because the distinction between "does/must contain" and "does/must not contain" is essential.
The quantity of the ingredient in a drug. This is represented/measured in various forms/units including: mg, mg/vol, %, etc.

Compound.451-EG (unit)
Essential for evaluating appropriate dosage based on strength, as well as for creating custom compounds with proper composition.

A pharmaceutical product to be supplied and/or administered to a patient. Encompasses manufactured drug products, generic classifications, prescription medications, over-the-counter medications and recreational drugs.
A_BillablePharmacyDispense
Allows drugs to be clearly described and referenced. Also allows searching for and examining information about medications that can be or are being used by a patient.
A catalog of drugs (manufactured material) from which drugs may be selected for prescribing/dispensing. This includes pre-manufactured drug products and previously prepared compounds.
A_BillablePharmacyDispense
Provides a list of drugs available for dispensing.
An identifier for a type of drug. Depending on where the drug is being referenced, the drug may be identified at different levels of abstraction. E.g. Manufactured drug (including vaccine).

RXA.5

A_BillablePharmacyDispense

Used to ensure clear communication by uniquely identifying a particular drug product when prescribing or dispensing. This attribute is only marked as 'populated' because some custom compounds will not have unique identifiers. Datatype has been retained as CE (Translatable Code) to support translation between multiple code sets for drugs (e.g. DIN, GTIN, UPC).
The name assigned to a drug.

Names are used for human reference communication, to allow selection from dropdowns and for local searching. If a code is available, the name acts as a cross-check. If the code is not available the name acts as the primary identifier. The attribute is therefore mandatory.
First occurrence is preferred for display.
A free form textual description of a drug. This usually is only populated for custom compounds, providing instructions on the composition and creation of the compound.

A_BillablePharmacyDispense

Dosage Form

Dosage Form
Provides a constrained vocabulary for describing dose forms. The form of the drug influences how it can be used by the patient.
Must be populated if the Drug Id does not specify the Drug Form.
Identification of a batch in which a specific manufactured drug belongs.

X0301

RXA.15

C.6

X0301

RXA.15

C.6

X0301

RXA.15

C.6
Useful in tracking for recalls but may not always exist.

Indicates either the length of time a drug product can remain viable (when talking about a drug in general terms), or the date on which the drug product is no longer considered viable (when talking about a specific medication that has been dispensed).

DispensedItem.expiryDate

Drug Expiry Date

C7

DispensedItem.expiryDate

Drug Expiry Date

C7

DispensedItem.expiryDate

Drug Expiry Date

C7
The potency, effectiveness and safety of drug products changes over time. When determining quantities to be supplied to a patient, one of the considerations is how long the drug will remain viable.
To indicate the length of time after opening a product remains viable, specify the 'Width' property. To indicate a specific end date for an actual dispensed product, specify the 'High' property
Describes the container in which a drug product can be or should be provided to the patient.
A_BillablePharmacyDispense
Aids patients in adhering to administration instructions (e.g. snap caps). May also influence the quantity prescribed.
A coded value denoting a specific kind of a container. Used to identify a requirement for a particular type of compliance packaging
Many insurance plans require that a prescriber specifically authorize the use of compliance packaging before it will be covered by the plan.
A list of drugs, chemicals or excipients that may or may not be present in a manufactured drug or a custom compound.
Important for expressing strength of active ingredients within a drug product, for expressing compound recipes, and for identifying potential causes for adverse reactions.
The unique identifier for the drug or chemical.

ZCP.2

Allows un-ambiguous identification of the ingredients of a drug for performing various alert checking.

Also allows for the identification of antigens as specific class of ingredients in vaccines.

Allows un-ambiguous identification of the ingredients of a drug for performing various alert checking.

Also allows for the identification of antigens as specific class of ingredients in vaccines.
The name of the contained drug or chemical.
CompoundIngredient.IngredientDrug.drugProductName
Used for communication between and display to providers.
Information about how the dispensed drug is or should be contained
A_BillablePharmacyDispense
May influence prescribing quantities, and also allows conveying instructions with respect to special packaging such as compliance packaging.
The quantity of the medication dosage form contained in the package given or to be given to the patient.

ZDP.10.2.2

ZDP.9.2.2

ZDP.10.2.2

ZDP.9.2.2
Sometimes ordering and dispensing is by package rather than individual units, and package is important in calculating total amount supplied.
Identification of which ingredients are contained (or are not contained) in a drug, along with their respective quantities.

Useful to providers in deciding appropriate use instruction (dosage specification) for patients. Also important in checking for potential adverse reactions to non-active ingredients. For compounds, allows contraindication checking against ingredients of custom compounds.
An indication that a drug does not contain the specified ingredient (active or inactive).

Useful for filtering searches. Allows providers to search for drugs not containing a specific active ingredients or excipients. E.g. lactose-free, gluten-free, etc.

The attribute is 'populated' because the distinction between "does/must contain" and "does/must not contain" is essential, however in some circumstances it is necessary to say "may contain".

Useful for filtering searches. Allows providers to search for drugs not containing a specific active ingredients or excipients. E.g. lactose-free, gluten-free, etc.

The attribute is 'populated' because the distinction between "does/must contain" and "does/must not contain" is essential, however in some circumstances it is necessary to say "may contain".
The quantity of the ingredient in a drug. This is represented/measured in various forms/units including: mg, mg/vol, %, etc.

Compound.448-ED (quantity)

Compound.451-EG (unit)
Essential for evaluating appropriate dosage based on strength, as well as for creating custom compounds with proper composition.
Associates a drug product with the organization responsible for producing it.
May be important for tracing adverse events and for performing drug searches.
Identity of the organization that manufactured the drug product.
Useful in distinguishing and grouping drug products
An identifier denoting a specific drug manufacturer.
Allows sending of identifiers in place of manufacturer name. May be used in drug search where specific manufacturer is a criterion.
The name of the drug manufacturer.

Used in reporting.

The attribute is marked as "mandatory" because there will always be a name for an organization.

Used in reporting.

The attribute is marked as "mandatory" because there will always be a name for an organization.

A pharmaceutical product to be supplied and/or administered to a patient. Encompasses manufactured drug products, generic classifications, prescription medications, over-the-counter medications and recreational drugs.
A_BillablePharmacyDispense
Allows drugs to be clearly described and referenced. Also allows searching for and examining information about medications that can be or are being used by a patient.
An identifier for a type of drug. Depending on where the drug is being referenced, the drug may be identified at different levels of abstraction. E.g. Manufactured drug (including vaccine).

Used to ensure clear communication by uniquely identifying a particular drug product when prescribing or dispensing. This attribute is only marked as 'populated' because some custom compounds will not have unique identifiers. Datatype has been retained as CE (Translatable Code) to support translation between multiple code sets for drugs (e.g. DIN, GTIN, UPC).
The name assigned to a drug.

Names are used for human reference communication, to allow selection from dropdowns and for local searching. If a code is available, the name acts as a cross-check. If the code is not available the name acts as the primary identifier. The attribute is therefore mandatory.

Dosage Form
Provides a constrained vocabulary for describing dose forms. The form of the drug influences how it can be used by the patient.
Must be populated if the Drug Id does not specify the Drug Form.
Identification of a batch in which a specific manufactured drug belongs.

Useful in tracking for recalls but may not always exist.

Indicates either the length of time a drug product can remain viable (when talking about a drug in general terms), or the date on which the drug product is no longer considered viable (when talking about a specific medication that has been dispensed).

DispensedItem.expiryDate

Drug Expiry Date

C7

DispensedItem.expiryDate

Drug Expiry Date

C7

DispensedItem.expiryDate

Drug Expiry Date

C7
The potency, effectiveness and safety of drug products changes over time. When determining quantities to be supplied to a patient, one of the considerations is how long the drug will remain viable.
To indicate the length of time after opening a product remains viable, specify the 'Width' property. To indicate a specific end date for an actual dispensed product, specify the 'High' property
Describes the container in which a drug product can be or should be provided to the patient.
A_BillablePharmacyDispense
Aids patients in adhering to administration instructions (e.g. snap caps). May also influence the quantity prescribed.
A coded value denoting a specific kind of a container. Used to identify a requirement for a particular type of compliance packaging
Many insurance plans require that a prescriber specifically authorize the use of compliance packaging before it will be covered by the plan.
A list of drugs, chemicals or excipients that may or may not be present in a manufactured drug or a custom compound.
Important for expressing strength of active ingredients within a drug product, for expressing compound recipes, and for identifying potential causes for adverse reactions.
The unique identifier for the drug or chemical.

Allows for lookup and retrieval of detailed information about a specific service location. Also ensures unique identification of service location and is therefore mandatory.

The identifier is mandatory because it is the principal mechanism for uniquely identifying the facility.

Allows for lookup and retrieval of detailed information about a specific service location. Also ensures unique identification of service location and is therefore mandatory.

The identifier is mandatory because it is the principal mechanism for uniquely identifying the facility.
The information by which a service location may be contacted either physically or by mail.

Identifies the physical location of a service location and also allows for the location to be contacted.

The address is marked as 'populated' because it is considered a critical piece of information about the facility, but may not always be available or meaningful.

Identifies the physical location of a service location and also allows for the location to be contacted.

The address is marked as 'populated' because it is considered a critical piece of information about the facility, but may not always be available or meaningful.
The phone numbers and/or electronic mail addresses by which a service location may be contacted.
Allows a service location to be communicated with and is therefore important. Because a contact number won't always exist, the field is marked 'populated'.
The type of patient information that can be accessed or modified.

Different consents (or even keywords) may be needed to access different types of patient information (e.g. demographics, medications, allergies, lab results). Understanding the type of information the consent applies to is critical, and therefore the attribute is mandatory.
Indicates that the consent was provided by the patient or representative.

Authorization.Person

Authorization.signatory(PT)

Authorization.Person

Authorization.signatory(PT)
Consent can be provided by the patient or representative or the provider.
Indicates whether the patient's consent is written or verbal.
Verbal consents may trigger a higher level of auditing.
Indicates the keyword appropriate to the action being performed by the message.
Allows providers who know the keyword to access information protected by patient keywords.
Indicates that information access was approved by a provider rather than a patient. I.e. This is an override rather than an actual consent, and is used for the purposes of 'breaking the glass' only.
Authorization.signatory(PROV)
Clinical circumstances may demand that a patient's information be accessed without consent to ensure patient safety.
Information pertaining to a patient's agreement/acceptance to have his/her clinical information electronically stored and shared.

Provides authorization to record and/or view patient information.

Indicates the consent or keyword used to authorize access or update, including a reason for access; May also be used to override access restriction to the information ('break the glass') on a message by message basis. May be required on a Prescription Request to indicate a keyword for DUR processing.

Provides authorization to record and/or view patient information.

Indicates the consent or keyword used to authorize access or update, including a reason for access; May also be used to override access restriction to the information ('break the glass') on a message by message basis. May be required on a Prescription Request to indicate a keyword for DUR processing.
The keywords will not be passed from prescriber to dispenser by the DIS.
A unique identifier for a specific consent for a patient.
Authorization.formNumber
Provides a traceable audit link between a physical consent form and its electronic record
Authorization.dataType
Indicates the time that the consent will expire. 'Low' is effective time and 'High' is end time.
Authorization.endTime (high)
Most consents are not open-ended, to ensure the patient retains a level of control.
Indicates a reason for overriding a patient's consent rules.

Authorization.reason (mnemonic)

Authorization.comment (original text)

Authorization.reason (mnemonic)

Authorization.comment (original text)
Important for audit purposes
Defines the types of information permission is being granted to access.
Allows discrete control over different types of information.
Indicates that the consent or keyword has been provided by the patient themselves (rather than a representative.)
Distinguishing whether consent is granted by the patient or a representative can be important for audit purposes.
Identifies the beneficiary of the consent as being a Provider or Service Location.

Indicates who is receiving consent to view information.

This participation is marked as "populated" as receiver must be specified when keyword is involved.

Indicates who is receiving consent to view information.

This participation is marked as "populated" as receiver must be specified when keyword is involved.
The patient's record the consent is associated with.
Essential for knowing what patient the consent is for, and therefore mandatory.
Provides information on how the message should be routed within the receiving application.
Allows direction of messages within complex applications. This association is optional because not all applications will require this level of routing.
A particular type of guidance for routing the message.
Allows categorization of routing types or support for multiple route pieces. Mandatory to understand the routing information.
Indicates the specific value used to route the item.
Allows internal routing within an application.
The unique identifier of the application or system from where the message is being sent.
Because this is the key identifier of where the message is coming from, this attribute is mandatory.
This is the name associated with the system or application sending the message.
Provides useful information when debugging.
Provides additional information about the configuration of the sending application. Useful when debugging.
Provides additional information that may assist in debugging interactions.
Indicates the last time the sending application was modified or reconfigured.
Can help to isolate the source of a problem when debugging.
Indicates the version number of the piece of software used to construct the message.
May be used to filter messages based on the compliance testing of the sending software.
Indicates the name of the software used to construct the message.
May be used to filter messages based on sending application compliance testing.
The unique identifier of the application to which the message is being sent.
Used for routing and for verification that "yes, this message is intended for me." This is mandatory because it is the key identifier of the receiving application.
The system to which responses are to be directed.
Provides support for directing responses to applications other than the original sender.
The unique identifier of the applications to which responses should be sent. Only populated when different from the sending application id.
Allows unique identification and routing to the application to be responded to. This attribute is mandatory be cause it is the principal identifier of the application to respond to.
The root class of all messages.
Conveys information about the interaction and how it is to be processed
A unique identifier for the message.
Allows detection of duplicate messages, and allows tying acknowledgments to the message they are acknowledging. The attribute is therefore mandatory.
Indicates the time this particular message instance was constructed.

Allows identification of how current the information in a message is. Also provides a baseline for identifying the time-zone of other times within the message. As a result, the attribute is mandatory.
A locally-defined field used to maintain a session, identify a user, and/or perform some other function related to authenticating the message source.
Allows jurisdictions and applications to communicate authentication and session information. The attribute is optional because not all jurisdictions will require this capability.
Indicates the version of the messaging standard being referenced.
Needed to know how to validate message definition, CMET definition, vocabulary and other information and is therefore mandatory.
Indicates the interaction conveyed by this message.
Identifies what the receiving application should do, and how the message should be validated. The attribute is therefore mandatory.
Identifies the conformance profile(s) this message complies with.
Indicates any additional validation that may be appropriate. Also influences what extensions can be processed.
Indicates whether this message is intended to be processed as production, test or debug message.
Indicates how the message should be handled and is therefore mandatory.
Indicates how the message is expected to be acknowledged.
Provides support for immediate, deferred and polling mode and distinguishes which mode is desired. The attribute is therefore mandatory.
Uniquely identifies the legal entity responsible for the content of the message.

May be used for routing/filtering purposes. Also allows tracking of the original responsible party for messages which may undergo multiple routing or translation steps. This attribute is optional because not all environments require communicating this information.
The unique identifier of the organization with responsibility to act on the contents of this message.

Important when the eventual entity responsible for acting on an interaction may be reached through several routing steps. This attribute is optional because not all environments require communicating this information.
The unique identifier of the application who is to be responsible for responses to this message.

Needed for circumstances where the 'respond to' organization is different than the sending organization. This attribute is optional because not all environments require communicating this information.
The unique identifier of the hospital, clinic or other facility which constructed the message.
May be used for routing, or for configuration control. This attribute is optional because not all environments require communicating this information.
Identifies the facility expected to receive the message.
May be used to assist in routing the message. This attribute is optional because not all environments require communicating this information.
Indicates the clinic or other facility to which responses to this interaction should be sent.
May affect the routing of a message. This attribute is optional because not all environments require communicating this information.
The address to which this message is being sent.
Indicates where the message should be sent. This is optional because not all environments require network addresses.
Indicates the interaction that should receive the response to this interaction. Used when different from the sender of the original interaction.

In complex routing environments, the acknowledgements may need to be sent to a system other than the one which constructed the original message. This association is optional because not all environments will support responses to systems other than the original sender.
Indicates the address to send acknowledgments of this message to.
Needed when the address to respond to is different than that of the sender. This is optional because not all environments require network addresses.
The network address of the application which sent the message.
May be important for sender validation. Usually also the address to which responses are sent. This is optional because not all environments require network addresses.
Indicates whether the previous interaction was successfully processed.
Key to understanding whether the interaction has been successful and is therefore mandatory.
For applications which support polling, indicates the total number of messages waiting to be retrieved.
Indicates to a system how many polled messages are available without the need so send a separate query. The element is optional because not all systems will support polling.
Indicates the priority of the highest-priority message that is waiting on the poll queue for the system being responded to.
The priority of the waiting message may influence how quickly the polling system may choose to download queued messages. The element is optional because not all systems will support polling.
An error, warning or information message associated with the message being acknowledged.
Allows identification issues related to the parsing and low-level processing of the message.
Distinguishes between errors, warnings and information messages.
Different types of messages have substantially different ramifications. As a result, the element is mandatory.
Indicates the specific issue represented by this message.

By providing coded identification of issues and errors, allows applications to have logic that manages particular errors and warnings automatically. However in some circumstances, a code may not be available. Therefore the attribute is marked as 'populated'.
The human-readable description of the error, warning or information message. May convey additional details not present in the 'code', but is not intended to be human-processable.
Allows supplementing the 'computer' information for human-readability.
Indicates the location of the elements within the message instance that triggered this error, warning or information message.
Allows syntax and other messages to be linked to particular fields within the message.
I.e. only the default 'child' axis is permitted, occurrence numbers are always specified, and no other predicates are permitted.

Information pertaining to a specific instance of drug characteristic (color - red, shape - triangular, markings etc).

Provides the 'value' part of the name-value pair describing the characteristic of drug product to be retrieved. Example:

type: color

value: blue

type: shape

value: rectangular

The attribute is mandatory because there's no point searching for a characteristic without specifying a value.

Provides the 'value' part of the name-value pair describing the characteristic of drug product to be retrieved. Example:

type: color

value: blue

type: shape

value: rectangular

The attribute is mandatory because there's no point searching for a characteristic without specifying a value.

Provides the 'value' part of the name-value pair describing the characteristic of drug product to be retrieved. Example:

type: color

value: blue

type: shape

value: rectangular

The attribute is mandatory because there's no point searching for a characteristic without specifying a value.

Provides the 'value' part of the name-value pair describing the characteristic of drug product to be retrieved. Example:

type: color

value: blue

type: shape

value: rectangular

The attribute is mandatory because there's no point searching for a characteristic without specifying a value.

Provides the 'value' part of the name-value pair describing the characteristic of drug product to be retrieved. Example:

type: color

value: blue

type: shape

value: rectangular

The attribute is mandatory because there's no point searching for a characteristic without specifying a value.

Provides the 'value' part of the name-value pair describing the characteristic of drug product to be retrieved. Example:

type: color

value: blue

type: shape

value: rectangular

The attribute is mandatory because there's no point searching for a characteristic without specifying a value.
Indicates the characteristic to be searched by.
Allows searching by appearance characteristics of the drug.
A coded value denoting the type of physical characteristic of a drug. Characteristics include: Color, Shape, Markings, Size, etc.

Allows retrieval based on specific characteristic of a drug. The attribute is mandatory because there's no point searching for a characteristic without identifying what kind of characteristic is being searched by.
Filters medications by their appearance.
Used to hold characteristic type and value pair as one set of query parameter item.

An identifier that describes a drug at any level of the clinical drug hierarchy. The code may describe (point to) a Manufactured drug, generic drug formulation, generic drug, therapeutic classification, etc.

For example, using a therapeutic class code in the DrugCode parameter would return a list of all drugs that are within that class. Sending a drug name in the DrugName parameter would return a list of all drugs that have that name e.g. sending acetaminophen would return all of the acetaminophen products in the drug data base. By including the DoseForm, DoseRoute, DrugManufacturerName or DrugCharacteristic, the list could be further constrained.

An identifier that describes a drug at any level of the clinical drug hierarchy. The code may describe (point to) a Manufactured drug, generic drug formulation, generic drug, therapeutic classification, etc.

For example, using a therapeutic class code in the DrugCode parameter would return a list of all drugs that are within that class. Sending a drug name in the DrugName parameter would return a list of all drugs that have that name e.g. sending acetaminophen would return all of the acetaminophen products in the drug data base. By including the DoseForm, DoseRoute, DrugManufacturerName or DrugCharacteristic, the list could be further constrained.
Allows the requester to retrieve drugs of certain abstraction only. These drug abstractions include: Manufactured drug, generic formulation, generic, therapeutic class, etc.
Indicates the form in which the drug product must is manufactured.
Useful filter for searching drugs. Allows the requester to specify the drug form of interest for the retrieval.
The name of a drug manufacturer.
Allows for the retrieval of drug products based on the manufacturer.
Manufacturer name search will be 'Starts with...' type of a search.
The name assigned to a drug.
Name may be the only identification of a drug known by many prescribers.
A filter based on how the drug should be introduced into the patient's body (e.g. Oral, topical, etc.)
Allows limiting the returned list of drugs to a single route.
Defines the set of parameters that may be used to filter the query response.
Root class for query parameters
The characteristics of a manufactured product that visually distinguish it from other products.
Used for searching drugs. May be employed as means of communication between providers and patients.
A coded value denoting the type of physical characteristic being documented. Kinds of characteristics include: Color, Shape, Markings, Size, etc.
Identifies what kind of characteristic is being identified. This is mandatory as providing the characteristic alone without specifying the type can result in ambiguity.
Information pertaining to a specific instance of drug characteristic (color, shape, markings etc).

Provides the 'value' part of the name-value pair describing the drug product appearance characteristic.

The attribute is marked as "mandatory" as there must be a value for a mandatory code.

Provides the 'value' part of the name-value pair describing the drug product appearance characteristic.

The attribute is marked as "mandatory" as there must be a value for a mandatory code.
Information about how the dispensed drug is or should be contained
A_BillablePharmacyDispense
May influence prescribing quantities, and also allows conveying instructions with respect to special packaging such as compliance packaging.
The quantity of the medication dosage form contained in the package given or to be given to the patient.

ZDP.10.2.2

ZDP.9.2.2

ZDP.10.2.2

ZDP.9.2.2
Sometimes ordering and dispensing is by package rather than individual units, and package is important in calculating total amount supplied.
Identification of which ingredients are contained (or are not contained) in a drug, along with their respective quantities.

Useful to providers in deciding appropriate use instruction (dosage specification) for patients. Also important in checking for potential adverse reactions to non-active ingredients. For compounds, allows contraindication checking against ingredients of custom compounds.
An indication that a drug does not contain the specified ingredient (active or inactive).

Useful for filtering searches. Allows providers to search for drugs not containing a specific active ingredients or excipients. E.g. lactose-free, gluten-free, etc.

Because product descriptions (particularly herbals) occasionally use the phrase "may contain", this attribute allows null values.

Useful for filtering searches. Allows providers to search for drugs not containing a specific active ingredients or excipients. E.g. lactose-free, gluten-free, etc.

Because product descriptions (particularly herbals) occasionally use the phrase "may contain", this attribute allows null values.
The quantity of the ingredient in a drug. This is represented/measured in various forms/units including: mg, mg/vol, %, etc.

Essential for evaluating appropriate dosage based on strength, as well as for creating custom compounds with proper composition.
Associates a drug product with the organization responsible for producing it.
May be important for tracing adverse events and for performing drug searches.
Identity of the organization that manufactured the drug product.
Useful in distinguishing and grouping drug products
An identifier denoting a specific drug manufacturer.
Allows sending of identifiers in place of manufacturer name. May be used in drug search where specific manufacturer is a criterion.
The name of the drug manufacturer.

Used in reporting.

The attribute is marked as "mandatory" because there will always be a name for an organization.

Used in reporting.

The attribute is marked as "mandatory" because there will always be a name for an organization.
Represents a particular medicine or herbal product which might be prescribed or administered.
Allows retrieval of summary about one or more products when searching for a medication

An identifier for a type of drug. Depending on where the drug is being referenced, the drug may be identified at different levels of abstraction. E.g. Manufactured drug (including vaccines), generic formulation, generic, therapeutic class, etc.

Used to ensure clear communication by uniquely identifying a particular drug product when prescribing or dispensing. This attribute is only constrained to 'required' because some custom compounds will not have unique identifiers.
The name assigned to a drug.

Names are used for human reference communication, to allow selection from dropdowns and for local searching. Up to two names are supported: a 'search name' which is fully formed with no abbreviations, and a 'display name' which may contain abbreviations to fit within a smaller area on the screen. Because names are the one attribute that exist for all attributes, this element is mandatory.
A free form textual description of a drug. This usually is only recorded for custom compounds, providing instructions on the composition and creation of the compound.
Allows description of compound ingredients and/or recipe in free text form.
Indicates the form in which the drug product must be, or has been manufactured or custom prepared.
Provides a constrained vocabulary for describing dose forms. The form of the drug influences how it can be used by the patient.
A categorization system that shows where a drug fits into a hierarchy of drug classification. Examples include: therapeutic class, generic drug, generic formulation, and manufactured drug.
Allows filtering and drill-down of drug products, as well as decision making with respect to substitutability, etc.
An identifier for a drug at a higher level of abstraction.

Used to uniquely identify a particular drug product when prescribing/dispensing at a higher level of abstraction (e.g. generic drug, generic formulation).

This attribute is marked as "populated" as a drug code should be available in most cases.

Used to uniquely identify a particular drug product when prescribing/dispensing at a higher level of abstraction (e.g. generic drug, generic formulation).

This attribute is marked as "populated" as a drug code should be available in most cases.
The name assigned to the drug at the higher level of abstraction.
Generic Name

To display in dropdowns and for local searching.

This attribute is marked as "populated" as drug name should be available in most cases.

To display in dropdowns and for local searching.

This attribute is marked as "populated" as drug name should be available in most cases.
Describes the container in which a drug product can be or should be provided to the patient.
A_BillablePharmacyDispense

Used for informing dispenser of the need and authorization to dispense medication in a clinically approved container. Aids patients in adhering to administration instructions. May also influence the quantity prescribed.
A coded value denoting a specific kind of a container. Used to identify a requirement for a particular type of compliance packaging
Many insurance plans require that a prescriber specifically authorize the use of compliance packaging before it will be covered by the plan.
Suggested cost of a drug (unit cost).
Allows providers to evaluate patient's affordability status before prescribing a drug.
The average unit dose cost of the drug.
ZPJ2.2
May influence prescriber and pharmacists decisions as cost can impact compliance.
Indicates whether the drug is approved for use in Canada or not. (active = approved for use; pending or terminated = not approved for use)
Allows providers to evaluate the validity of the medication for use in Canada.
Indicates the location of a medication in a particular abstract hierarchy. For example, what generic, generic formulation, or therapeutic class does the medication fall into.

Shows relationship between GenericDrugproduct, Generic FormulationDrugProduct and ManufacturedDrugProduct

ZPC.7(query will reference the generic equivalency relationship in defining the boolean query parameter)

Shows relationship between GenericDrugproduct, Generic FormulationDrugProduct and ManufacturedDrugProduct

ZPC.7(query will reference the generic equivalency relationship in defining the boolean query parameter)

Exposes the drug hierarchy, allowing drill-down when prescribing and dispensing. Also indicates possibilities for substitution and can be important for detecting interactions such as allergies or duplicate therapy between closely-related drugs.
A coded value denoting a specific level in the hierarchical definition of drugs.
Describes the relationship between two levels of drug products (e.g. Drug A is the generic for Drug B)
Indicates the physical appearance characteristics of the drug, such as size, color, shape, markings, etc.

Patients are often unfamiliar with the names of their medications, but can describe them by appearance. At the same time, prescribers may be familiar with the name but not the appearance. This information eases communication between provider and patient and also may be used to search for a particular drug product by appearance characteristics.
A list of drugs or raw chemicals that may be present in a manufactured drug or a custom compound.
Important for expressing strength of active ingredients within a drug product, for expressing compound recipes, and for identifying potential causes for adverse reactions.
The unique identifier for the drug or chemical.

Establishes financial responsibility for the prescription as well as provide a means for the provider to engage in follow-up communication with the payor.

The payor for coverage extension must be known, thus this is a mandatory requirement.

Establishes financial responsibility for the prescription as well as provide a means for the provider to engage in follow-up communication with the payor.

The payor for coverage extension must be known, thus this is a mandatory requirement.
Identifies the instructions for how the prescribed device should be dispensed to the patient.
An essential part of most prescriptions is the authorization to dispense.
An authorization issued by a payor to cover a device not previously covered by a patient's drug plan.
Allows conveying special coverage information between providers.
If set to 'EVN', then coverage has been granted. Otherwise it has merely been requested.
Indicates to the pharmacy whether they need to check the status of coverage prior to dispensing
Unique identification for a specific coverage extension.

Allows for referencing of a specific coverage extension.

This identifier may be needed on claims against the coverage.

At times the ID will not be available (such as when the request has just been submitted), the attribute is 'populated'.

Allows for referencing of a specific coverage extension.

This identifier may be needed on claims against the coverage.

At times the ID will not be available (such as when the request has just been submitted), the attribute is 'populated'.

This identifier may be needed on claims against the coverage.

At times the ID will not be available (such as when the request has just been submitted), the attribute is 'populated'.
Indicates any extensions to the patient's insurance coverage that have been solicited by the prescriber, including indications of whether the requested extension was granted.
Helps streamline communication from prescriber to pharmacy by informing the pharmacy of whether an extension has already been requested, and if so, what the status is.
Identifies the address where the dispensed product is to be shipped.
Prescription.facility
Used when the device cannot/will not be picked up from the dispenser in person.
Information pertaining to a prescriber's authorization for a device to be dispensed to a patient, as well as the instruction on when and how the device is to be used by the patient
This is a 'core' class of the medication model and is important for understanding what devices the patient is intended to be receiving.

The Prescription Order Number is a globally unique number assigned to a prescription by the EHR/DIS irrespective of the source of the order

It is created by the EHR/DIS once the prescription has passed all edits and validation.

The Prescription Order Number is a globally unique number assigned to a prescription by the EHR/DIS irrespective of the source of the order

It is created by the EHR/DIS once the prescription has passed all edits and validation.

Allows for the situations where the order is originating from the DIS.

Allows prescriptions to be uniquely referenced.

Because this attribute is not used for prescriptions originating from a prescriber system, the element is optional.

Allows for the situations where the order is originating from the DIS.

Allows prescriptions to be uniquely referenced.

Because this attribute is not used for prescriptions originating from a prescriber system, the element is optional.

Allows for the situations where the order is originating from the DIS.

Allows prescriptions to be uniquely referenced.

Because this attribute is not used for prescriptions originating from a prescriber system, the element is optional.

This denotes the state of the prescription in the lifecycle of the prescription. Valid statuses are: new, active, suspended, aborted, completed, obsolete and nullified. Use 'active' when registering a new prescription or converting a predetermination into a valid prescription.
Indicates what actions are allowed to be performed against a prescription. This is a mandatory field because every prescription needs to be in some state.

Communicates the intent of the patient to restrict access to their prescriptions. Provides support for additional confidentiality constraint, giving patients a level of control over their information. Valid values are: 'NORMAL' (denotes 'Not Masked'); and 'RESTRICTED' (denotes 'Masked'). The default is 'NORMAL' signifying 'Not Masked'.
Prescription.masked

Allows the patient to have discrete control over access to their prescription data.

The attribute is optional because not all systems will support masking.

Allows the patient to have discrete control over access to their prescription data.

The attribute is optional because not all systems will support masking.
Indicates the device being prescribed.
This is a key aspect of the prescription and is therefore mandatory
Indicates the pharmacy to which the prescription has been directed or which has currently assumed responsibility for dispensing the prescription.

Allows prescriptions to be directed on the request of the patient or by legal requirement. Also allows indication of which pharmacy is the current 'custodian' of the prescription.

This should always be known or should have an explicit null flavor of 'NA' (non-assigned) or 'UNK' (paper prescription). Thus the association is 'populated'.

Allows prescriptions to be directed on the request of the patient or by legal requirement. Also allows indication of which pharmacy is the current 'custodian' of the prescription.

This should always be known or should have an explicit null flavor of 'NA' (non-assigned) or 'UNK' (paper prescription). Thus the association is 'populated'.
The date and time on which the dispense is expected to be picked up.
Allows a prescriber to indicate to the targeted pharmacy, when patient will be expecting to pick up the dispensed device.
The name of the organization responsible for issuing the coverage extension
Mandatory for display purposes.
If present, indicates that the prescription is non-authoritative. I.e. A paper copy must be viewed before the prescription can be dispensed.

Allows distinguishing prescriptions where the paper copy is authoritative vs. the electronic copy being authoritative.

This attribute behaves as a 'mandatory' element where the presence of the association indicates that a paper prescription is needed and the absence of the association indicates that one is not.

Allows distinguishing prescriptions where the paper copy is authoritative vs. the electronic copy being authoritative.

This attribute behaves as a 'mandatory' element where the presence of the association indicates that a paper prescription is needed and the absence of the association indicates that one is not.
Identifies the previous prescription that is being renewed by this order.
Allows tracking a therapy across multiple prescriptions.
A reference to a previous prescription which the current prescription replaces.
New or Repeat (if present, then Repeat)

Allows a prescription renewal (this prescription) to note the previous prescription id that was renewed;

Allows tracking a therapy across multiple renewal prescriptions.

Allows a prescription renewal (this prescription) to note the previous prescription id that was renewed;

Allows tracking a therapy across multiple renewal prescriptions.
Indicates how the device should be used by the patient.
Instructions are a key part of the prescription.
Denotes the reason(s) for this specific prescription; it must not be interpreted as a permanent diagnosis.

Helps providers evaluate the appropriateness of the instructions for the device, and may influence education or literature provided to the patient on the use of the device.

Provided at the discretion of the prescriber to enhance patient care.

This field is marked as populated because of its high clinical importance, however 'Nulls' are allowed because the individual recording the prescription (e.g. pharmacist) may not be aware of the indication or the prescriber may choose to withhold (mask) the information due to patient sensitivity.

Helps providers evaluate the appropriateness of the instructions for the device, and may influence education or literature provided to the patient on the use of the device.

Provided at the discretion of the prescriber to enhance patient care.

This field is marked as populated because of its high clinical importance, however 'Nulls' are allowed because the individual recording the prescription (e.g. pharmacist) may not be aware of the indication or the prescriber may choose to withhold (mask) the information due to patient sensitivity.

Helps providers evaluate the appropriateness of the instructions for the device, and may influence education or literature provided to the patient on the use of the device.

Provided at the discretion of the prescriber to enhance patient care.

This field is marked as populated because of its high clinical importance, however 'Nulls' are allowed because the individual recording the prescription (e.g. pharmacist) may not be aware of the indication or the prescriber may choose to withhold (mask) the information due to patient sensitivity.

Ordering of prescribing indications from primary indication (low number) to minor indication (higher number). Multiple indications are permitted to have the same priority if they're considered of equivalent importance.

Allows providers to indicate whether indication is the primary or secondary target of the therapy. E.g., Terazosin for Benign Prostatic Hypertrophy as primary and Hypertension as secondary or vice-versa.
Indicates the location the dispensed device should be shipped to, at the request of the patient or provider.
In some cases devices need to be delivered to the patient instead of being picked up. In other cases, devices need to be shipped to the physician's office to replace stock used for the patient.
Indicates the various comments that providers have recorded about this prescription.
Improves communication between providers by allowing a mechanism to exchange uncoded free-form information.
Identity of the person for whom the prescription is being created.
A legal requirement, and also allows the content to be linked to the person's EHR. As a result, this association is mandatory.
Specification of how the prescribed device is to be dispensed to the patient. Dispensed instruction information includes the quantity to be dispensed, how often the quantity is to be dispensed, etc.
A_BillablePharmacyDispense
Sets the parameters within which the dispenser must operate in dispensing the device to the patient.
The overall number of devices to be dispensed under this prescription. Includes any first fills (trials, aligning quantities), the initial standard fill plus all refills.

Sets upper limit for device to be dispensed. Can be used to verify the intention of the prescriber with respect to the overall prescription. Used for comparison when determining whether additional quantity may be dispensed in the context of a part-fill prescription.
The number of days that the overall prescribed item is expected to last, if the patient is compliant with the dispensing and use of the prescription.

Used to specify a total authorization as a duration rather than a quantity with refills. E.g. dispense 30 at a time, refill for 1 year. May also be sent as an estimate of the expected overall duration of the prescription based on the quantity prescribed.
A unique identifier for the payor organization responsible for the coverage extension.
Gives context to the coverage extension identifier and therefore mandatory. Allows the dispensing service delivery location to know where to send a claim.
Information pertaining to a prescriber's authorization for a drug to be dispensed to a patient, as well as the instruction on when and how the drug is to be consumed by the patient
This is a 'core' class of the medication model and is important for understanding what drugs the patient is intended to be receiving.

It is created by the EHR/DIS once the prescription has passed all edits and validation.
