Claim:414-DE

Indicates when the action was performed, and may influence expiry dates for the order.

The attribute is populated as it will not be there for inferred prescriptions.

Indicates when the action was performed, and may influence expiry dates for the order.

The attribute is populated as it will not be there for inferred prescriptions.
Indicates the days supply and quantity of devices dispensed.
Dispense is not complete without specifying quantity dispensed, and thus this association is mandatory.
Indicates that there are issues associated with this prescription.

The presence of issues can be of clinical significance and may prompt a clinician to wish to drill down for further information.

This element behaves as a mandatory attribute which is true when the association is present and false when it is absent.

The presence of issues can be of clinical significance and may prompt a clinician to wish to drill down for further information.

This element behaves as a mandatory attribute which is true when the association is present and false when it is absent.
Represents the dispensing of a device to a patient.
Communicates an overview of a patient's dispenses.

The Prescription Dispense Number is a globally unique number assigned to a dispense (single fill) by the EHR/DIS irrespective of the source of the dispense.

It is created by the EHR/DIS once the dispense has passed all edits and validation.

The Prescription Dispense Number is a globally unique number assigned to a dispense (single fill) by the EHR/DIS irrespective of the source of the dispense.

It is created by the EHR/DIS once the dispense has passed all edits and validation.

Allows for the referencing of a specific dispense record.

Identifier for a dispensed record is needed so that dispenses may be uniquely referenced. Thus the mandatory requirement.

Allows for the referencing of a specific dispense record.

Identifier for a dispensed record is needed so that dispenses may be uniquely referenced. Thus the mandatory requirement.

Indicates the status of the dispense record created on the EHR/DIS. If 'Active' it means that the dispense has been processed but not yet given to the patient. If 'Complete', it indicates that the medication has been delivered to the patient.
Important in understanding what medication the patient actually has on hand, thus the attribute is mandatory. May also influence the ability of a different pharmacy to dispense the medication.

Communicates the intent of the patient to restrict access to their prescriptions.

Provides support for additional confidentiality constraint, giving patients a level of control over their information.

Valid values are: 'NORMAL' (denotes 'Not Masked'); and 'RESTRICTED' (denotes 'Masked').

The default is 'NORMAL' signifying 'Not Masked'.

Communicates the intent of the patient to restrict access to their prescriptions.

Provides support for additional confidentiality constraint, giving patients a level of control over their information.

Valid values are: 'NORMAL' (denotes 'Not Masked'); and 'RESTRICTED' (denotes 'Masked').

The default is 'NORMAL' signifying 'Not Masked'.

Communicates the intent of the patient to restrict access to their prescriptions.

Provides support for additional confidentiality constraint, giving patients a level of control over their information.

Valid values are: 'NORMAL' (denotes 'Not Masked'); and 'RESTRICTED' (denotes 'Masked').

The default is 'NORMAL' signifying 'Not Masked'.

Communicates the intent of the patient to restrict access to their prescriptions.

Provides support for additional confidentiality constraint, giving patients a level of control over their information.

Valid values are: 'NORMAL' (denotes 'Not Masked'); and 'RESTRICTED' (denotes 'Masked').

The default is 'NORMAL' signifying 'Not Masked'.

Allows the patient to have discrete control over access to their medication data.

The attribute is optional because not all systems will support masking.

Allows the patient to have discrete control over access to their medication data.

The attribute is optional because not all systems will support masking.
Indicates the prescription that was dispensed.
Links the dispense act to the prescription order it was performed against.
Identification of the service delivery location where the device was dispensed.
Used for follow-up communication on the dispensed product, and therefore mandatory.
Identifier of the health service provider who dispensed the device to the patient.
Identity of the dispenser must be known, and therefore mandatory.
Identifies the product that was dispensed.
Identifies the device as part of the patient's profile. The device is one of the most important parts of the dispense record, and it is therefore mandatory.
Identity of the provider who is taking responsibility for the actions of the author.
Allows for the trail of responsibility for the action.
Identity of the provider who is taking responsibility for the actions of the author.
Allows for the trail of responsibility for the action.
If true, indicates that there are notes associated with the record.

Indicates whether there is information available on drill-down.

This element behaves as a mandatory attribute which is true when the association is present and false when it is absent.

Indicates whether there is information available on drill-down.

This element behaves as a mandatory attribute which is true when the association is present and false when it is absent.

Represents the date the dispense product was prepared and when the product was picked up by or delivered to the patient. The dispense processing date and pickup date can be back dated to reflect when the actual processing and pickup occurred. The lower-bound of the period signifies the dispense-processing date whereas the upper-bound signifies the dispense-pickup date.

Useful in monitoring patient compliance. May also be useful in determining and managing certain contraindications ('Fill-Too-Soon', 'Fill-Too-Late', and 'Duration of Therapy'). Because 'Days Supply' may be necessary to compute total dispensed quantity, it is made a 'populated' field.
A reference to the prescription order being dispensed
Links a dispense with its parent prescription.

This is an identifier assigned to a specific device order. The number remains constant across the lifetime of the order, regardless of the number of providers or pharmacies involved in fulfilling the order.

Allows prescriptions to be uniquely referenced and associated with the dispense.

The ID is mandatory because the DIS would always assign a Prescription Number.

Allows prescriptions to be uniquely referenced and associated with the dispense.

The ID is mandatory because the DIS would always assign a Prescription Number.

The identity of the person who was ultimately responsible for the drug substitution.

This is either the patient, the prescriber of the dispenser.

The identity of the person who was ultimately responsible for the drug substitution.

This is either the patient, the prescriber of the dispenser.
Provides a trace of responsibility for the dispensed drug.
Indicates the prescriber of the prescription.
The prescriber is a key piece of legal information which must be conveyed and is therefore mandatory.

The date at which the drug was prescribed. This may differ from the date on which the prescription becomes effective. E.g. A prescription created today may not be valid to be dispensed or administered for two weeks.

Indicates when the action was performed, and may influence expiry dates for the order.

The attribute is populated because the creation date of the prescription shall always be known or absent for a reason.

Indicates when the action was performed, and may influence expiry dates for the order.

The attribute is populated because the creation date of the prescription shall always be known or absent for a reason.
Identity of the health service provider or the application responsible for the change in the prescription dispense status.

In an EHR integrated health services environment, it is important that other providers are able to query who is responsible for status changes. Also used by applications for auditing and sorting. The attribute is mandatory because provider or application maintaining the prescription dispense must be known.
The date and time at which the change was made.

Gives other providers the frame of reference in evaluating any post-change issues with the prescription dispense. Also used for sorting and audit purposes.

The attribute is mandatory as the time of change is known.

Gives other providers the frame of reference in evaluating any post-change issues with the prescription dispense. Also used for sorting and audit purposes.

The attribute is mandatory as the time of change is known.
Indicates the days supply and quantity of medication dispensed.
Dispense is not complete without specifying quantity dispensed, and thus this association is mandatory.
Indicates how the drug is to be consumed by the patient.
It is important to understand the specific instructions that were provided to the patient. Therefore, the association is mandatory.
Indicates whether or not substitution was made as part of the prescription dispense.
Must be consistent with substitution directive from the prescription.
This records the history of changes that have been made to the prescription dispense, including why the changes were made, who made them and when.
Provides an audit trail of a patient's therapy adjustments. Status changes may affect evaluations of compliance.
Identifies what kind of change occurred. Examples include Suspended, Aborted, etc.
This attribute is mandatory to ensure that change types are distinguishable.

The date on which the various status changes of a prescription dispense become valid and applicable. In the case of a suspend, may also indicate the scheduled time at which the status change will end.

Allows applications to sort and filter by time.

The effective date can be defaulted to change date, and thus is mandatory.

Allows applications to sort and filter by time.

The effective date can be defaulted to change date, and thus is mandatory.
Denotes the reason the status of the prescription dispense was changed.
Ensures consistent terminology in capturing and interpreting reasons for change. Allows CWE because not all reasons will correspond to a pre-defined code.
Indicates where the dispensed product was sent.
A_BillablePharmacyDispense
Important as part of a claim for justifying shipping charges.
Indicates the prescription that was dispensed.
Links the dispense act to the prescription order it was performed against.
Indicates the facility/location where the dispensing was performed.
Important for performing follow-up and therefore mandatory.
Describes the issuing of a drug in response to an authorizing prescription.
This is a 'core' class of the medication model and is important for understanding what drugs the patient is actually receiving.

The Prescription Dispense Number is a globally unique number assigned to a dispense (single fill) by the EHR/DIS irrespective of the source of the dispense.

It is created by the EHR/DIS once the dispense has passed all edits and validation.

The Prescription Dispense Number is a globally unique number assigned to a dispense (single fill) by the EHR/DIS irrespective of the source of the dispense.

It is created by the EHR/DIS once the dispense has passed all edits and validation.

Allows for the referencing of a specific dispense record.

Identifier for a dispensed record is needed so that dispenses may be uniquely referenced. Thus the mandatory requirement.

Allows for the referencing of a specific dispense record.

Identifier for a dispensed record is needed so that dispenses may be uniquely referenced. Thus the mandatory requirement.

Indicates the status of the dispense record created on the EHR/DIS. If 'Active' it means that the dispense has been processed but not yet given to the patient. If 'Complete', it indicates that the medication has been delivered to the patient.
Important in understanding what medication the patient actually has on hand, thus the attribute is mandatory. May also influence the ability of a different pharmacy to dispense the medication.
Identification of the provider who dispensed the medication.
Important for tracking responsibility and for following up. This is an essential part of the record, and therefore is mandatory.
Identifies the product that was dispensed. Also provides information on compound ingredients and instructions and packaging requirements.
Identifies the drug as part of the patient's medication profile. The drug is one of the most important parts of the dispense record, and it is therefore mandatory.
Identifies the person who picked up the dispensed product for the patient.
Used when patient is not in a position to pick up medication.

Should only be populated if there is a specific need to track the person (other than the patient) who picked up the dispense (e.g. for narcotics). If populated and if a list of potential receivers have been identified by the Rx Order, then this person should be one of those listed.
Indicates the person who was responsible for making the substitution decision.
Who made the substitution decision may affect the decision of how much to reimburse.
Identification of the provider who was supervising the actions of the author.
Allows for the trail of responsibility for the action.
Identity of the provider who is taking responsibility for the actions of the author.
Allows for the trail of responsibility for the action.
Identity of the provider who is taking responsibility for the actions of the author.
Allows for the trail of responsibility for the action.
The location where the dispensed product is expected to be delivered.
Important as part of a claim for justifying shipping charges.
Indicates where the dispensed product was sent.
Important as part of a claim for justifying shipping charges.
Shows how the status of the dispense has changed over time.
Dispense records can change status from 'active' to 'completed' or even 'aborted'. This allows providers to understand exactly when those changes took place.
If true, indicates that there are notes associated with the record.
Indicates whether there is information available on further drill-down. The element behaves as a mandatory attribute interpreted as 'true' when the association is present, 'false' otherwise.
Indicates that there are issues associated with this record.

The presence of issues can be of clinical significance and may prompt a clinician to wish to drill down for further information. The element behaves as a mandatory attribute interpreted as 'true' when the association is present, 'false' otherwise.

Detailed information indicating identified issues (permission problems, drug-drug interactions, dosage issues, duplicate therapy, drug-allergy, drug-lab, age appropriateness, etc.) with the proposed prescription dispense, along with how the issues have been managed by the dispenser.
Allows a dispenser to override alerts and business rules, as well as providing a permanent record of management steps.
Indicates the various comments that providers have recorded about this dispense record.
Improves communication between providers by allowing a mechanism to exchange un-coded free-form information.
A reference to the prescription order being dispensed
Links a dispense with its parent prescription.

This is an identifier assigned to a specific medication order. The number remains constant across the lifetime of the order, regardless of the number of providers or pharmacies involved in fulfilling the order.

Allows prescriptions to be uniquely referenced and associated with the dispense.

The ID is mandatory because the DIS will always assign a Prescription Order Number.

Allows prescriptions to be uniquely referenced and associated with the dispense.

The ID is mandatory because the DIS will always assign a Prescription Order Number.
An indication of what kind of substitution made, if any.

May explain why prescribed and dispensed medications differ.
A code signifying whether a different drug was dispensed from what was prescribed.

Useful in monitoring patient compliance. May also be useful in determining and managing certain contraindications ('Fill-Too-Soon', 'Fill-Too-Late', and 'Duration of Therapy'). Because 'Days Supply' may be necessary to compute total dispensed quantity, it is made a 'populated' field.

A free form textual specification generated from the input specifications as created by the provider.

This is made up of either an 'Ad-hoc dosage instruction' or 'Textual rendition of the structured dosage lines', plus route, dosage unit, and other pertinent administration information specified by the provider.

A free form textual specification generated from the input specifications as created by the provider.

This is made up of either an 'Ad-hoc dosage instruction' or 'Textual rendition of the structured dosage lines', plus route, dosage unit, and other pertinent administration information specified by the provider.

Allows the provider to verify the codified structured dosage information entered and ensure that the exploded instruction is consistent with the intended instructions.

Also useful in bringing back administration instructions on query responses. Because all prescriptions and dispenses have dosage, this attribute is mandatory.

Allows the provider to verify the codified structured dosage information entered and ensure that the exploded instruction is consistent with the intended instructions.

Also useful in bringing back administration instructions on query responses. Because all prescriptions and dispenses have dosage, this attribute is mandatory.

For dosage instructions which cannot be summarized in the space allocated, a string such as "Complex dose" or "Scaling dose" or something similar should be sent. Dosage instructions should never be truncated.
This is the provider who authorized the medication to be dispensed to the patient.

Links the dispense act to the prescription order it was performed against.
Identification of the service delivery location where the medication was dispensed.
Used for follow-up communication on the dispensed product, and therefore mandatory.
Describes the issuing of a drug in response to an authorizing prescription.
This is a 'core' class of the medication model and is important for understanding what drugs the patient is actually receiving.

The Prescription Dispense Number is a globally unique number assigned to a prescription dispense by the EHR/DIS irrespective of the source of the supply event

It is created by the EHR/DIS once the dispense has passed all edits and validation.

The Prescription Dispense Number is a globally unique number assigned to a prescription dispense by the EHR/DIS irrespective of the source of the supply event

It is created by the EHR/DIS once the dispense has passed all edits and validation.
Allows dispense events to be uniquely referenced and is therefore mandatory.
Indicates whether the dispense has been picked up ('complete') or has just been processed ('active').
Indicates how far along the process the dispense event is. It should always be known and is therefore mandatory.

Communicates the intent of the patient to restrict access to their prescriptions.

Provides support for additional confidentiality constraint, giving patients a level of control over their information.

Valid values are: 'NORMAL' (denotes 'Not Masked'); and 'RESTRICTED' (denotes 'Masked').

The default is 'NORMAL' signifying 'Not Masked'.

Communicates the intent of the patient to restrict access to their prescriptions.

Provides support for additional confidentiality constraint, giving patients a level of control over their information.

Valid values are: 'NORMAL' (denotes 'Not Masked'); and 'RESTRICTED' (denotes 'Masked').

The default is 'NORMAL' signifying 'Not Masked'.

Communicates the intent of the patient to restrict access to their prescriptions.

Provides support for additional confidentiality constraint, giving patients a level of control over their information.

Valid values are: 'NORMAL' (denotes 'Not Masked'); and 'RESTRICTED' (denotes 'Masked').

The default is 'NORMAL' signifying 'Not Masked'.

Communicates the intent of the patient to restrict access to their prescriptions.

Provides support for additional confidentiality constraint, giving patients a level of control over their information.

Valid values are: 'NORMAL' (denotes 'Not Masked'); and 'RESTRICTED' (denotes 'Masked').

The default is 'NORMAL' signifying 'Not Masked'.

Allows the patient to have discrete control over access to their medication data.

The attribute is optional because not all systems will support masking.

Allows the patient to have discrete control over access to their medication data.

The attribute is optional because not all systems will support masking.
Identifier of the health service provider who dispensed the medication to the patient.
Identity of the dispenser must be known, and therefore mandatory.
Identifies the product that was dispensed. Also provides information on compound ingredients and instructions and packaging requirements.
Identifies the drug as part of the patient's medication profile. The drug is one of the most important parts of the dispense record, and it is therefore mandatory.
Identity of the provider who is taking responsibility for the actions of the author.
Allows for the trail of responsibility for the action.
Identification of the provider who was supervising the actions of the author.
Allows for the trail of responsibility for the action.
If true, indicates that there are notes associated with the record.
Indicates whether there is information available on drill-down. The element behaves as a mandatory attribute interpreted as 'true' when the association is present, 'false' otherwise.
Indicates that there are issues associated with this prescription.

The presence of issues can be of clinical significance and may prompt a clinician to wish to drill down for further information. The element behaves as a mandatory attribute interpreted as 'true' when the association is present, 'false' otherwise.
Indicates the order being dispensed
Provides a drill-down link from the prescription to its corresponding order.

The Prescription Order Number is a globally unique number assigned to a prescription by the EHR/DIS irrespective of the source of the order

It is created by the EHR/DIS once the prescription has passed all edits and validation.

The Prescription Order Number is a globally unique number assigned to a prescription by the EHR/DIS irrespective of the source of the order

It is created by the EHR/DIS once the prescription has passed all edits and validation.

Links the dispense to the prescription it fulfilled.

Represents the date the dispense product was prepared and when the product was picked up by or delivered to the patient. The dispense processing date and pickup date can be back dated to reflect when the actual processing and pickup occurred. The lower-bound of the period signifies the dispense-processing date whereas the upper-bound signifies the dispense-pickup date.

A_BillablePharmacyDispense

Days Supply

DispensedItem.daysSupply

Useful in monitoring patient compliance. May also be useful in determining and managing certain contraindications ('Fill-Too-Soon', 'Fill-Too-Late', and 'Duration of Therapy'). Because 'Days Supply' may be necessary to compute total dispensed quantity, it is made a 'populated' field.
A textual rendition of structured (or non-structure) original dosage instruction specified by the prescriber.

Allows the prescriber to verify the structured dosage instruction.

Attribute is marked as "mandatory" as the rendition of the dosage instruction must always be made available to the prescriber.

Allows the prescriber to verify the structured dosage instruction.

Attribute is marked as "mandatory" as the rendition of the dosage instruction must always be made available to the prescriber.
Indicates the provider who recorded the "other active medication".
Useful for follow-up and audit purposes, and therefore mandatory.
This is the provider who authorized the medication to be dispensed to the patient.

To be a legal order, the person responsible for its creation must be identified. Thus the association is mandatory.
The date that the prescription was written by the prescriber.

Essential information for a prescription to be legal.

This information may not always be known for an inferred prescription, and is therefore marked as "populated".

Essential information for a prescription to be legal.

This information may not always be known for an inferred prescription, and is therefore marked as "populated".
Indicates who refused to fulfill the prescription
Allows follow-up and traceability of the refusal and is therefore mandatory
Information pertaining to a Prescriber's authorization for a drug to be dispensed to a patient, as well as the instruction on when and how the drug is to be administered to the patient.
This is a 'core' class of the medication model and is important for understanding what drugs the patient is intended to be receiving.
Where the prescription is for a combination of drugs (e.g. 10mg tablets + 40mg tablets) repeatNumber cannot be populated and quantity must be expressed in mg.

The Prescription Order Number is a globally unique number assigned to a prescription by the EHR/DIS irrespective of the source of the order

It is created by the EHR/DIS once the prescription has passed all edits and validation.

The Prescription Order Number is a globally unique number assigned to a prescription by the EHR/DIS irrespective of the source of the order

It is created by the EHR/DIS once the prescription has passed all edits and validation.

Allows prescriptions to be uniquely referenced.

The number is mandatory to allow every prescription record to be uniquely identified.

Allows prescriptions to be uniquely referenced.

The number is mandatory to allow every prescription record to be uniquely identified.
Indicates that this is a prescription for a drug as opposed to an immunization. For SNOMED, may also contain information regarding drug and route.

Needed to convey the meaning of this class and is therefore mandatory.

The element allows 'CD' to provide support for SNOMED.

Needed to convey the meaning of this class and is therefore mandatory.

The element allows 'CD' to provide support for SNOMED.
This denotes the state of the prescription in the lifecycle of the prescription. Valid statuses are: NEW, ACTIVE, SUSPENDED, ABORTED, COMPLETED, OBSOLETE and NULLIFIED.

Prescription.state (cannot distinguish between 'Filled' and 'Unfilled', must look at amounts dispensed to distniguish between those; and also cannot distinguish modified, need to look at event history).

Prescription Status

Prescription.state (cannot distinguish between 'Filled' and 'Unfilled', must look at amounts dispensed to distniguish between those; and also cannot distinguish modified, need to look at event history).

Prescription Status

Indicates what actions are allowed to be performed against a prescription.

This is a mandatory field because every prescription needs to be in some state.

Indicates what actions are allowed to be performed against a prescription.

This is a mandatory field because every prescription needs to be in some state.

Communicates the intent of the patient to restrict access to their prescriptions.

Provides support for additional confidentiality constraint, giving patients a level of control over their information.

Valid values are: 'NORMAL' (denotes 'Not Masked'); and 'RESTRICTED' (denotes 'Masked').

The default is 'NORMAL' signifying 'Not Masked'.

Communicates the intent of the patient to restrict access to their prescriptions.

Provides support for additional confidentiality constraint, giving patients a level of control over their information.

Valid values are: 'NORMAL' (denotes 'Not Masked'); and 'RESTRICTED' (denotes 'Masked').

The default is 'NORMAL' signifying 'Not Masked'.

Communicates the intent of the patient to restrict access to their prescriptions.

Provides support for additional confidentiality constraint, giving patients a level of control over their information.

Valid values are: 'NORMAL' (denotes 'Not Masked'); and 'RESTRICTED' (denotes 'Masked').

The default is 'NORMAL' signifying 'Not Masked'.

Communicates the intent of the patient to restrict access to their prescriptions.

Provides support for additional confidentiality constraint, giving patients a level of control over their information.

Valid values are: 'NORMAL' (denotes 'Not Masked'); and 'RESTRICTED' (denotes 'Masked').

The default is 'NORMAL' signifying 'Not Masked'.
Prescription.masked

Allows the patient to have discrete control over access to their medication data.

The attribute is optional because not all systems will support masking.

Allows the patient to have discrete control over access to their medication data.

The attribute is optional because not all systems will support masking.
The Prescriber's instruction(s) for the administration of the medication.

This information is needed for a prescription to be valid and is therefore mandatory. Multiple repetitions are supported for circumstances where a single therapy involves the administration of multiple drugs. E.g. Didrocal.
Indicates the clinical use category in which the prescription has been put.
Allows prescriptions to be categorized in multiple ways.
Identifies the instructions for how the prescribed medication should be dispensed to the patient.

An essential part of most prescriptions is the authorization to dispense. Multiple repetitions are included to accommodate circumstances where multiple drug products may need to be dispensed to complete a therapy. E.g. 100 x 20mg tablets and 50 x 10mg tablets. The association is marked as Populated because the authorization to dispense is a critical portion of a prescription. However the association is allowed to be 'null' when the order is for a medication which requires no dispense authorization (e.g. over-the-counter medications), or when the patient already has sufficient supply of the medication on hand to complete the therapy.
Identifies the other active medication being recorded into the system as being taken by the patient.
The drug is the key part of the administration record, and is therefore mandatory.
Describes an issue associated with a prescription that resulted in a dispenser refusing to fill it.
Allows a dispenser to assert an issue against a prescription to be displayed to subsequent dispensers as well as others reviewing the patient's medication profile.

A coded value that is used to distinguish between different kinds of issues. Types of issue include: unrecognized identifiers, permission issues, drug-drug contraindications, drug-allergy alerts, duplicate therapies, suspect fraud etc.

Identifies what kind of issue was detected or is being managed.

This is mandatory so as to ensure that one issue type can be distinguished from another.

Identifies what kind of issue was detected or is being managed.

This is mandatory so as to ensure that one issue type can be distinguished from another.
A free form textual description regarding the issue of fraudulence. This may be specified in place of, or in addition to the coded issue.
Enables extra or more detailed description of the alert
Indicates the medication that has been prescribed to the patient.

This is a key aspect of the prescription.

Because SNOMED can coordinate drug into code, this association is only 'required'.

This is a key aspect of the prescription.

Because SNOMED can coordinate drug into code, this association is only 'required'.
Provides summary information about future dispenses.
Helps provide an overview of the prescription.
Provides summary information about future dispenses.
Helps provide an overview of the prescription.
Provides summary information about the first dispense made on the prescription.
Helps provide an overview of the prescription.
Provides summary information about the most recent dispense on the prescription.
Helps provide an overview of the prescription.
Identifies a location where the refusal occured
Allows follow-up and traceability of the refusal and is therefore mandatory
Identification of the service delivery location where the other active medication was recorded
Used for follow-up communication on the dispensed product, and therefore mandatory.
Indicates the pharmacy to which the prescription has been directed or which has currently assumed responsibility for dispensing the prescription.

Allows prescriptions to be directed on the request of the patient or by legal requirement. Also allows indication of which pharmacy is the current 'custodian' of the prescription.

This should always be known or should have an explicit null flavor of 'NA' (non-assigned) or 'UNK' (paper prescription). Thus the association is 'populated'.

Allows prescriptions to be directed on the request of the patient or by legal requirement. Also allows indication of which pharmacy is the current 'custodian' of the prescription.

This should always be known or should have an explicit null flavor of 'NA' (non-assigned) or 'UNK' (paper prescription). Thus the association is 'populated'.

Indicates a 'hard' or 'soft' assignment of dispensing priviledged to the targeted facility.

'Hard' assignment (mandated facility) indicates that the prescription can be dispensed only at that facility.

'Soft' assignment (usually as a patient directive) indicates that the prescription may be dispensed at facilities other than the targeted facility.

Indicates a 'hard' or 'soft' assignment of dispensing priviledged to the targeted facility.

'Hard' assignment (mandated facility) indicates that the prescription can be dispensed only at that facility.

'Soft' assignment (usually as a patient directive) indicates that the prescription may be dispensed at facilities other than the targeted facility.

Indicates a 'hard' or 'soft' assignment of dispensing priviledged to the targeted facility.

'Hard' assignment (mandated facility) indicates that the prescription can be dispensed only at that facility.

'Soft' assignment (usually as a patient directive) indicates that the prescription may be dispensed at facilities other than the targeted facility.
Influences whether the prescription may be transferred to a service delivery location other than the targeted dispenser.
Indicates the clinic or facility which originally issued the prescription.
Identifies where paper records are likely located for follow-up. This is marked as 'populated' because it won't always be known for 'inferred prescriptions.

A record of a medication the patient is believed to be taking, but for which an electronic order does not exist. "Other medications" include any drug product deemed relevant to the patient's drug profile, but which was not specifically ordered by a prescriber in a DIS-enabled jurisdiction. Examples include over-the counter medications that were not specifically ordered, herbal remedies, and recreational drugs. Prescription drugs that the patient may be taking but was not prescribed on the EHR (e.g. institutionally administered or out-of-jurisdiction prescriptions) will also be recorded here.
Necessary component of a person's overall medication profile. Allows DUR checking against a more complete drug profile.
This is an identifier assigned to a unique instance of an other medication record.
Allows for the unique referencing of a specific other medication record. Thus the mandatory requirement. .
Indicates that the record is a drug administration rather than an immunization or other type of administration. For SNOMED, may also include route, drug and other information.

Needed to convey the meaning of this class and is therefore mandatory.

The element allows 'CD' to provide support for SNOMED.

Needed to convey the meaning of this class and is therefore mandatory.

The element allows 'CD' to provide support for SNOMED.
Indicates the status of the other medication record created on the EHR/DIS. Valid statuses for other medication records are: ACTIVE, COMPLETE only.

Used to determine whether the medication should be considered in performing DUR checking and therefore mandatory.

Note ------ The provider might know that the patient is not taking the medication but not necessarily when the patient stopped it. Thus the status of the medication could be set to 'COMPLETED' by the provider without necessarily setting an End Date on the medication record.

Used to determine whether the medication should be considered in performing DUR checking and therefore mandatory.

Note ------ The provider might know that the patient is not taking the medication but not necessarily when the patient stopped it. Thus the status of the medication could be set to 'COMPLETED' by the provider without necessarily setting an End Date on the medication record.
Indicates the time-period in which the patient has been taking or is expected to be taking the active medication.

Used to indicate help determine whether the medication is currently active. Because this information won't always be available, the attribute is marked as 'populated'.
Denotes access restriction place on the other medication record. Methods for accessing masked other medications will be governed by each jurisdiction (e.g. court orders, shared secret/consent, etc.).

Provides support for additional confidentiality constraint to reflect the wishes of the patient.

The attribute is optional because not all systems will support masking.

Provides support for additional confidentiality constraint to reflect the wishes of the patient.

The attribute is optional because not all systems will support masking.

Ensures consistency in description of routes. Provides potential for cross-checking dosage form and route. Because this information is pre-coordinated into 'code' for SNOMED, it is marked as optional.

Ensures consistency in description of routes. Provides potential for cross-checking dosage form and route.

Because this information can be pre-coordinated with code by SNOMED, the attribute is optional.

Ensures consistency in description of routes. Provides potential for cross-checking dosage form and route.

Because this information can be pre-coordinated with code by SNOMED, the attribute is optional.
If present, indicates that the prescription is non-authoritative. I.e. A paper copy must be viewed before the prescription can be dispensed.

Allows distinguishing prescriptions where the paper copy is authoritative vs. the electronic copy being authoritative.

This attribute behaves as a 'mandatory' element where the presence of the association indicates that a paper prescription is needed and the absence of the association indicates that one is not.

Allows distinguishing prescriptions where the paper copy is authoritative vs. the electronic copy being authoritative.

This attribute behaves as a 'mandatory' element where the presence of the association indicates that a paper prescription is needed and the absence of the association indicates that one is not.
Denotes the reason(s) for this specific prescription; it must not be interpreted as a permanent diagnosis.

Helps providers evaluate the appropriateness of the dosage instructions for the medication, and may influence education or literature provided to the patient on the use of the medication.

Provided at the discretion of the prescriber to enhance patient care. E.g., take 1 tab bid for migraine. Also needed for drug-disease interaction checking software to work properly.

This field is marked as populated because of its high clinical importance, however 'Nulls' are allowed because the individual recording the prescription (e.g. pharmacist) may not be aware of the indication or the prescriber may choose to withhold (mask) the information due to patient sensitivity.

Helps providers evaluate the appropriateness of the dosage instructions for the medication, and may influence education or literature provided to the patient on the use of the medication.

Provided at the discretion of the prescriber to enhance patient care. E.g., take 1 tab bid for migraine. Also needed for drug-disease interaction checking software to work properly.

This field is marked as populated because of its high clinical importance, however 'Nulls' are allowed because the individual recording the prescription (e.g. pharmacist) may not be aware of the indication or the prescriber may choose to withhold (mask) the information due to patient sensitivity.

Helps providers evaluate the appropriateness of the dosage instructions for the medication, and may influence education or literature provided to the patient on the use of the medication.

Provided at the discretion of the prescriber to enhance patient care. E.g., take 1 tab bid for migraine. Also needed for drug-disease interaction checking software to work properly.

This field is marked as populated because of its high clinical importance, however 'Nulls' are allowed because the individual recording the prescription (e.g. pharmacist) may not be aware of the indication or the prescriber may choose to withhold (mask) the information due to patient sensitivity.

Ordering of prescribing indications from primary indication (low number) to minor indication (higher number). Multiple indications are permitted to have the same priority if they're considered of equivalent importance.

Allows providers to indicate whether indication is the primary or secondary target of the therapy. E.g., Terazosin for Benign Prostatic Hypertrophy as primary and Hypertension as secondary or vice-versa.
Identifies an issue as the reason for recording a refusal to fill against a prescription.
Allows a dispenser to point to an issue of 'suspect fraud' as the reason for recording a 'refusal to fill' against a prescription.
Indicates that the identified issue resulted in a dispenser refusing to fill the subject prescription.

Exposes in the model that this issue is associated with a refusal to dispense.

An indication of 'refusal to fill' must be indicated, thus attribute is mandatory.

Exposes in the model that this issue is associated with a refusal to dispense.

An indication of 'refusal to fill' must be indicated, thus attribute is mandatory.
Indicates a non-clinical-issue based reason for refusing to fill.
Supports capture of reasons such as 'moral objection' which are not tied to specific issues. Set to CWE to allow non-coded reasons.
Identity of the provider who is taking responsibility for the actions of the author.
Allows for the trail of responsibility for the action.
Identity of the provider who is taking responsibility for the actions of the author.
Allows for the trail of responsibility for the action.
If present, indicates that the data associated with the prescription is uncertain because the existence of the prescription has been inferred from a secondary source (e.g. dispensing data).

Distinguishes electronic records which reflect exactly what was ordered from orders that merely mimic what was dispensed and therefore can't be used for information about ordering patterns. Because it must always be known how an order was captured, this attribute is mandatory.
If present, indicates that there are notes associated with the record.

Indicates whether there is information available on drill-down.

This association is mandatory as it indicates one of presence or absence of notes.

Indicates whether there is information available on drill-down.

This association is mandatory as it indicates one of presence or absence of notes.
Indicates the patient who is taking the drug product.
Essential for linking the active medication to the patient's record, and is therefore mandatory.
Indicates that there are issues associated with this prescription.

The presence of issues can be of clinical significance and may prompt a clinician to wish to drill down for further information.

This association is mandatory as it indicates one of presence or absence of issues.

The presence of issues can be of clinical significance and may prompt a clinician to wish to drill down for further information.

This association is mandatory as it indicates one of presence or absence of issues.
Indicates refusals that have been recorded against the prescription
Makes information about prior refusals to subsequent pharmacies, as well as to the prescriber
Identity of the person for whom the prescription was created.

A legal requirement, and also allows the content to be linked to the person's EHR. As a result, this association is mandatory.
If present, indicates that there are notes associated with the record.

Indicates whether there is information available on drill-down.

This association is mandatory as it indicates one of presence or absence notes.

Provides summary information about the first dispense event on the prescription
Useful in understanding the status of a prescription and in planning for renewals.
Indicates when the first dispense against the prescription was picked up.

Useful in establishing start of therapy.

Important information for compliance

Useful in establishing start of therapy.

Important information for compliance
Indicates the amount of medication first dispensed on the prescription.

Usually establishes trial quantities for a prescription.

Because the quantity should always be known if the first dispense is known, this attribute is mandatory.

Usually establishes trial quantities for a prescription.

Because the quantity should always be known if the first dispense is known, this attribute is mandatory.
Provides summary information about what dispenses remain to be performed against the prescription
Useful in understanding the status of a prescription and in planning for renewals.
Indicates the number of remaining dispenses estimated, assuming that each fill is equal to the quantity prescribed for a single fill, rounding up.
Indicates the number of dispenses that may still occur.
Indicates the total remaining undispensed quantity authorized against the prescription.
Indicates how much can still be dispensed.
Provides summary information about the most recent dispense event performed against the prescription
Useful in understanding the status of a prescription and in planning for renewals.
Indicates the most recent date on which a dispense on the prescription was picked up.
Useful in determining when a prescription will next need to be dispensed. Also provides an indication of compliance.
Indicates the most recent quantity of the drug that was picked up for the prescription.

Useful in determining amount of medication that a patient should have on-hand. Also provides an indication of compliance.

Because the quantity should always be known if the last dispense is known, this attribute is mandatory.

Useful in determining amount of medication that a patient should have on-hand. Also provides an indication of compliance.

Because the quantity should always be known if the last dispense is known, this attribute is mandatory.
Summarizes the dispenses that have happened against the prescription to date.
Helps in understanding the status of the prescription and evaluating compliance.

documentation.businessName: Number of Fills Made Against Rx

annotation.text: Indicates the number of dispense events performed against the prescription to date, including trial, partial and complete fills.
Useful in tracking the progress of a prescription in prescription.
Indicates the amount of medication that has been dispensed to date.
Useful for tracking the progress of a prescription.

This generally mirrors the status for the prescription, but in some circumstances may be changed to 'aborted' while the prescription is still active. When this occurs, it means the prescription may no longer be dispensed, though it may still be administered.

Allows the dispensing authorization of the prescription to be controlled/manipulates as needed.

Attribute is marked as "mandatory" as the dispensing authority of the prescription will always be known.

Allows the dispensing authorization of the prescription to be controlled/manipulates as needed.

Attribute is marked as "mandatory" as the dispensing authority of the prescription will always be known.
The overall amount of amount medication to be dispensed under this prescription. Includes any first fills (trials, aligning quantities), the initial standard fill plus all refills.

Sets upper limit for medication to be dispensed. Can be used to verify the intention of the prescriber with respect to the overall medication. Used for comparison when determining whether additional quantity may be dispensed in the context of a part-fill prescription.
Categorization of prescriptions based on the intended duration of the prescribed therapy.
Useful in establishing compliance for drug renewals and refills.
Describes the categorization of the therapy envisioned by this prescription (e.g. Continuous/Chronic, Short-Term/Acute and "As-Needed).

Prescription type

Prescription.drugUseIndicator

Prescription type

Prescription.drugUseIndicator

Allows categorizing prescription for presentation. May influence detection of duplicate therapy. May also be used to affect how DUR processing is completed. The field is marked as "populated" because the intended duration of the therapy should generally be known at prescribe time. However in some circumstances, it may not be known whether a therapy will be short-term or long-term.
Indicates the identity of the provider who recorded the other medication information.
Allows other providers to enquire about the authenticity of the content of the other medication record and is therefore mandatory.
Identity of the health service provider or the application responsible for the change in the other medication status.

In an EHR integrated health services environment, it is important that other providers are able to query who is responsible for status changes. Also used by applications for auditing and sorting. The attribute is marked as "mandatory" because provider or application maintaining the other medication must be known.
The date and time at which the change was made.

Gives other providers the frame of reference in evaluating any post-change issues with the other medication. Also used for sorting and audit purposes.

Attribute is marked as "mandatory" as the time of change must be known.

Gives other providers the frame of reference in evaluating any post-change issues with the other medication. Also used for sorting and audit purposes.

Attribute is marked as "mandatory" as the time of change must be known.
Indicates how the drug is to be consumed by the patient.
When available, it is important to understand the specific instructions that were provided to the patient.
Identifies the other medication being recorded into the system as being taken by the patient.
The drug is the key part of the administration record, and is therefore mandatory.
This records the history of changes that have been made to the other medication record, including why the changes were made, who made them and when.
Provides an audit trail of a patient's use of other medications.
Identifies what kind of change occurred. Examples include Completed, Aborted, etc.
This attribute is mandatory to ensure that change types are distinguishable

documentation.businessName: Other Medication Status Change Effective Period

annotation.text: The date on which the various status changes of an other medication record become valid and applicable. In the case of a suspend, may also indicate the scheduled time at which the status change will end.

Allows applications to sort and filter by time.

The effective date can be defaulted to change date, and thus is mandatory.

Allows applications to sort and filter by time.

The effective date can be defaulted to change date, and thus is mandatory.
Denotes the reason the status of the other medication was changed.
Ensures consistent terminology in capturing and interpreting reasons for change. Allows CWE because not all reasons will correspond to a pre-defined code.
Indicates the facility/location where the other medication was recorded.
Important for performing follow-up and is therefore mandatory.

A record of a medication the patient is believed to be taking, but for which an electronic order does not exist. "Other active medications" include any drug product deemed relevant to the patient's drug profile, but which was not specifically ordered by a prescriber in a DIS-enabled jurisdiction. Examples include over-the counter medications that were not specifically ordered, herbal remedies, and recreational drugs. Prescription drugs that the patient may be taking but was not prescribed on the EHR (e.g. institutionally administered or out-of-jurisdiction prescriptions) will also be recorded here.
Necessary component of a person's overall medication profile. Allows DUR checking against a more complete drug profile.
This is an identifier assigned to a unique instance of an active medication record.
Allows for the unique referencing of a specific active medication record. Thus the mandatory requirement. .
Indicates that the record is a drug administration rather than an immunization or other type of administration. For SNOMED, may also include route, drug and other information.

Needed to convey the meaning of this class and is therefore mandatory.

The element allows 'CD' to provide support for SNOMED.

Needed to convey the meaning of this class and is therefore mandatory.

The element allows 'CD' to provide support for SNOMED.
Indicates the status of the other medication record created on the EHR/DIS. Valid statuses for other medication records are: 'active' and 'completed' only.

Used to determine whether the medication should be considered in performing DUR checking.

Attribute is mandatory to ensure that a medication recorded in EHR/DIS is in some state.

Note ------ The provider might know that the patient is not taking the medication but not necessarily when the patient stopped it. Thus the status of the medication could be set to 'completed' by the provider without necessarily setting an End Date on the medication record.

Used to determine whether the medication should be considered in performing DUR checking.

Attribute is mandatory to ensure that a medication recorded in EHR/DIS is in some state.

Note ------ The provider might know that the patient is not taking the medication but not necessarily when the patient stopped it. Thus the status of the medication could be set to 'completed' by the provider without necessarily setting an End Date on the medication record.

Used to determine whether the medication should be considered in performing DUR checking.

Attribute is mandatory to ensure that a medication recorded in EHR/DIS is in some state.

Note ------ The provider might know that the patient is not taking the medication but not necessarily when the patient stopped it. Thus the status of the medication could be set to 'completed' by the provider without necessarily setting an End Date on the medication record.
Indicates the time-period in which the patient has been taking or is expected to be taking the medication.

Used to help determine whether the medication is currently active. Because this information won't always be available, the attribute is marked as 'populated'.
Denotes access restriction place on the other medication record. Methods for accessing masked other medications will be governed by each jurisdiction (e.g. court orders, shared secret/consent, etc.).

Provides support for additional confidentiality constraint to reflect the wishes of the patient.

The attribute is optional because not all systems will support masking.

Provides support for additional confidentiality constraint to reflect the wishes of the patient.

The attribute is optional because not all systems will support masking.
This is the means by which the patient is taking the medication.

Route of administration

Ensures consistency in description of routes. Provides potential for cross-checking dosage form and route. Because this information is pre-coordinated into 'code' for SNOMED, it is marked as optional.
Identity of the provider who is taking responsibility for the actions of the author.
Allows for the trail of responsibility for the action.
Identity of the provider who is taking responsibility for the actions of the author.
Allows for the trail of responsibility for the action.

Detailed information indicating identified issues (permission problems, drug-drug interactions, dosage issues, duplicate therapy, drug-allergy, drug-lab, age appropriateness, etc.) with the proposed medication, along with how the issues have been managed by the recorder.
Allows a recorder to override alerts and business rules, as well as providing a permanent record of management steps.
Indicates the patient who is taking the drug product.
Essential for linking the other medication to the patient's record, and is therefore mandatory.
Shows how the status of the active medication has changed over time.
Allows providers to understand what the status of a particular active medication was on a given date. Historical statuses may impact views of compliance.
Indicates the various comments that providers have recorded about this medication record.
Improves communication between providers by allowing a mechanism to exchange un-coded free-form information.
If present, indicates that there are notes associated with the record.

Indicates whether there is information available on further drill-down. The association behaves as a mandatory boolean attribute where the presence of the association indicates true and the absence of the association indicates false.
Indicates that there are issues associated with this record.

The presence of issues can be of clinical significance and may prompt a clinician to wish to drill down for further information. The association behaves as a mandatory boolean attribute where the presence of the association indicates true and the absence of the association indicates false.

The identity of the person who was ultimately responsible for the drug substitution.

This is either the patient, the prescriber of the dispenser.

The identity of the person who was ultimately responsible for the drug substitution.

This is either the patient, the prescriber of the dispenser.
Provides a trace of responsibility for the dispensed drug.
Indicates who refused to fulfill the prescription

Allows follow-up and traceability of the refusal.

Association is mandatory as the provider refusing the fill must be known.

Allows follow-up and traceability of the refusal.

Association is mandatory as the provider refusing the fill must be known.

Allows for pure electronic prescriptions without a trusted intermediary. The attribute is optional because all jurisdictions may not support digital signatures.
A unique identifier for the payor organization responsible for the coverage extension.
Gives context to the coverage extension identifier and therefore mandatory. Allows the dispensing service delivery location to know where to send a claim.
Information pertaining to a Prescriber's authorization for a drug to be dispensed to a patient, as well as the instruction on when and how the drug is to be administered to the patient.
This is a 'core' class of the medication model and is important for understanding what drugs the patient is intended to be receiving.

It is created by the EHR/DIS once the prescription has passed all edits and validation.

Allows prescriptions to be uniquely referenced.

The number is mandatory to allow every prescription record to be uniquely identified.

Allows prescriptions to be uniquely referenced.

The number is mandatory to allow every prescription record to be uniquely identified.

Local systems may assign their own internal number to a prescription, and MAY display and print that number on the printed prescription, bottle labels, etc. However, the globally-unique DIS-assigned number MUST be displayed and printed.
Indicates that this is a prescription for a drug as opposed to an immunization. For SNOMED, may also contain information regarding drug and route.

Needed to convey the meaning of this class and is therefore mandatory.

The element allows 'CD' to provide support for SNOMED.

Needed to convey the meaning of this class and is therefore mandatory.

The element allows 'CD' to provide support for SNOMED.
This denotes the state of the prescription in the lifecycle of the prescription. Valid statuses are: NEW, ACTIVE, SUSPENDED, ABORTED, COMPLETED, OBSOLETE and NULLIFIED.

Prescription.state (cannot distinguish between 'Filled' and 'Unfilled', must look at amounts dispensed to distniguish between those; and also cannot distinguish modified, need to look at event history).

Prescription Status

Prescription.state (cannot distinguish between 'Filled' and 'Unfilled', must look at amounts dispensed to distniguish between those; and also cannot distinguish modified, need to look at event history).

Prescription Status

Indicates what actions are allowed to be performed against a prescription.

This is a mandatory field because every prescription needs to be in some state.

Indicates what actions are allowed to be performed against a prescription.

This is a mandatory field because every prescription needs to be in some state.

Communicates the intent of the patient to restrict access to their prescriptions.

Provides support for additional confidentiality constraint, giving patients a level of control over their information.

Valid values are: 'NORMAL' (denotes 'Not Masked'); and 'RESTRICTED' (denotes 'Masked').

The default is 'NORMAL' signifying 'Not Masked'.

Communicates the intent of the patient to restrict access to their prescriptions.

Provides support for additional confidentiality constraint, giving patients a level of control over their information.

Valid values are: 'NORMAL' (denotes 'Not Masked'); and 'RESTRICTED' (denotes 'Masked').

The default is 'NORMAL' signifying 'Not Masked'.

Communicates the intent of the patient to restrict access to their prescriptions.

Provides support for additional confidentiality constraint, giving patients a level of control over their information.

Valid values are: 'NORMAL' (denotes 'Not Masked'); and 'RESTRICTED' (denotes 'Masked').

The default is 'NORMAL' signifying 'Not Masked'.

Communicates the intent of the patient to restrict access to their prescriptions.

Provides support for additional confidentiality constraint, giving patients a level of control over their information.

Valid values are: 'NORMAL' (denotes 'Not Masked'); and 'RESTRICTED' (denotes 'Masked').

Prescription.masked

Allows the patient to have discrete control over access to their medication data.

The attribute is optional because not all systems will support masking.

Allows the patient to have discrete control over access to their medication data.

The attribute is optional because not all systems will support masking.
Indicates the days supply and quantity of medication dispensed.
Dispense is not complete without specifying quantity dispensed, and thus this association is mandatory.
The Prescriber's instruction(s) for the administration of the medication.

This information is needed for a prescription to be valid and is therefore mandatory. Multiple repetitions are supported for circumstances where a single therapy involves the administration of multiple drugs. E.g. Didrocal.
Indicates how the drug is to be consumed by the patient.
It is important to understand the specific instructions that were provided to the patient. Therefore, the association is mandatory.
Indicates whether or not substitution was made as part of the prescription dispense.
Must be consistent with substitution directive from the prescription.
Indicates that a prescription is part of a Trial Program.
Serves as reminder for dispenser to consider option of part-filling. In some jurisdictions, the prescription must be so designated by the prescriber for the dispenser to do trial dispensing.
An indication that a prescription is or is not eligible for trial dispensing from a clinical (not financial) perspective. False = Eligible, True = Not Eligible.

May affect dispensers' discretion to dispense anything other than prescribed fill quantity.

Expressed as 'Non-Eligibility' rather than 'Eligibility' due to restrictions in HL7 modeling.

The attribute is mandatory because it must be known whether trials are allowed or not.

May affect dispensers' discretion to dispense anything other than prescribed fill quantity.

Expressed as 'Non-Eligibility' rather than 'Eligibility' due to restrictions in HL7 modeling.

The attribute is mandatory because it must be known whether trials are allowed or not.

May affect dispensers' discretion to dispense anything other than prescribed fill quantity.

Expressed as 'Non-Eligibility' rather than 'Eligibility' due to restrictions in HL7 modeling.

The attribute is mandatory because it must be known whether trials are allowed or not.
Identifies the instructions for how the prescribed medication should be dispensed to the patient.

An essential part of most prescriptions is the authorization to dispense. Multiple repetitions are included to accommodate circumstances where multiple drug products may need to be dispensed to complete a therapy. E.g. 100 x 20mg tablets and 50 x 10mg tablets. The association is marked as Populated because the authorization to dispense is a critical portion of a prescription. However the association is allowed to be 'null' when the order is for a medication which requires no dispense authorization (e.g. over-the-counter medications), or when the patient already has sufficient supply of the medication on hand to complete the therapy.
Indicates the clinical use category in which the prescription has been put.
Allows prescriptions to be categorized in multiple ways.
Identifies the instructions for how the prescribed medication should be dispensed to the patient.

An essential part of most prescriptions is the authorization to dispense. Multiple repetitions are included to accommodate circumstances where multiple drug products may need to be dispensed to complete a therapy. E.g. 100 x 20mg tablets and 50 x 10mg tablets. The association is marked as Populated because the authorization to dispense is a critical portion of a prescription. However the association is allowed to be null when the order is for a medication which requires no dispense authorization (e.g. over-the-counter medications), or when the patient already has sufficient supply of the medication on hand to complete the therapy.
Indicates the date and quantity for the first dispense on the prescription, as well as count-down of refills dispensed.

Used in case of trial prescription or in situations where the first fill may be different from subsequent fills for administrative or non-clinical reasons (e.g. to align the refill dates of a series of prescriptions).
Indicates the number of refills permitted on the prescription.
Used for compliance checking
This records the history of changes that have been made to the prescription, including why the changes were made, who made them and when.
Provides an audit trail of a patient's therapy adjustments. Status changes may affect evaluations of compliance.
Identifies what kind of change occurred. Examples include Suspended, Superseded, Released, Aborted (stopped), etc.
Distinguishes discontinueStatus, holdStatus, reactivateStatus and releaseStatus
This attribute is mandatory to ensure that change types are distinguishable.
The date on which the various status changes of a prescription become valid and applicable. In the case of a suspend, may also indicate the scheduled time at which the status change will end.

Allows applications to sort and filter by time.

The effective date can be defaulted to change date, and thus is mandatory.

Allows applications to sort and filter by time.

The effective date can be defaulted to change date, and thus is mandatory.
Denotes the reason the status of the prescription was changed.

PrescriptionStatus.reason(mnemonic)

PrescriptionStatus.adhocReason(originalText)

PrescriptionStatus.reason(mnemonic)

PrescriptionStatus.adhocReason(originalText)
Ensures consistent terminology in capturing and interpreting reasons for change. Allows CWE because not all reasons will correspond to a pre-defined code.
An authorization issued by a payor to cover a drug not previously covered by a patient's drug plan.
Allows conveying special coverage information between providers.
If set to 'EVN', then coverage has been granted. Otherwise it has merely been requested.
Indicates to the pharmacy whether they need to check the status of coverage prior to dispensing. The element is mandatory to satisfy HL7 rules.
Unique identification for a specific coverage extension.

Allows for referencing of a specific coverage extension.

This identifier may be needed on claims against the coverage.

At times the ID will not be available (such as when the request has just been submitted), the attribute is 'populated'.

Allows for referencing of a specific coverage extension.

This identifier may be needed on claims against the coverage.

At times the ID will not be available (such as when the request has just been submitted), the attribute is 'populated'.

Allows for referencing of a specific coverage extension.

This identifier may be needed on claims against the coverage.

At times the ID will not be available (such as when the request has just been submitted), the attribute is 'populated'.
Indicates any extensions to the patient's insurance coverage that have been solicited by the prescriber, including indications of whether the requested extension was granted.
Helps streamline communication from prescriber to pharmacy by informing the pharmacy of whether an extension has already been requested, and if so, what the status is.
Enables the communication of a reference to a protocol, study or guideline id, specific to the jurisdiction
Supporting references
Provides support for non-traditional therapies. Needed when seeking to prescribe Special Access medications. E.g. Ontario Limited Use program.
Identifies the location where the dispensed product is to be shipped, at the request of the patient or provider.
Used when the medication cannot/will not be picked up from the dispenser in person.
Indicates where the dispensed product was sent.
A_BillablePharmacyDispense
Important as part of a claim for justifying shipping charges.
Describes an issue associated with a prescription that resulted in a dispenser refusing to fill it.
Allows a dispenser to assert an issue against a prescription to be displayed to subsequent dispensers as well as others reviewing the patient's medication profile.

A coded value that is used to distinguish between different kinds of issues. Types of issue include: unrecognized identifiers, permission issues, drug-drug contraindications, drug-allergy alerts, duplicate therapies, suspect fraud etc.

Identifies what kind of issue was detected or is being managed.

This is mandatory so as to ensure that one issue type can be distinguished from another.

Identifies what kind of issue was detected or is being managed.

This is mandatory so as to ensure that one issue type can be distinguished from another.
A free form textual description regarding the issue of fraudulence. This may be specified in place of, or in addition to the coded issue.
Enables extra or more detailed description of the alert
Indicates the medication that has been prescribed to the patient.

This is a key aspect of the prescription.

Because SNOMED can pre-coordinate the drug into code, this association is only 'required'

This is a key aspect of the prescription.

Because SNOMED can pre-coordinate the drug into code, this association is only 'required'
Shows the prescription dispenses that have occurred against this prescription.

Helps the prescriber evaluate patient compliance. Allows the prescriber to see what specific medications have been dispensed to the patient and provides a more complete view of the patient's medical profile.
Provides summary information about past dispenses.
Helps provide an overview of the prescription.
Provides summary information about future dispenses.
Helps provide an overview of the prescription.
Provides summary information about the first dispense made on the prescription.
Helps provide an overview of the prescription.
Provides summary information about the most recent dispense on the prescription.
Helps provide an overview of the prescription.
Special instructions regarding the very first supply of medication to a patient.
Allows a different amount to be dispensed on an initial fill, either as a trial or to synchronize refill dates across multiple patient prescriptions
The date before which an initial dispense can be made against the prescription. If an initial fill has not been made against the prescription in this time-period, it may not be dispensed.

Some jurisdictions have distinct stale-date periods for the initial fill of a prescription from the overall dispensing of the prescription. E.g. 'The first fill must be made within 1 year, all fills must be complete within 1.5 years'. (This attribute would be used for the '1 year'.)
The quantity of medication to be dispensed the first time the prescription is dispensed against.
Prescription.coordinatingAmount
Allows a limited quantity to be dispensed for a trial or for a synchronizing dose.
The number of days that the first fill is expected to last, if the patient is compliant with the dispensing of the first fill and with administration of the prescription.
Used when the prescriber cannot or does not wish to calculate the quantity necessary to last for the trial or synchronization time.
Indicates the facility/location where the dispensing was performed.
Important for performing follow-up and therefore mandatory.
Identifies the location where the refusal occurred
Allows follow-up and traceability of the refusal and is therefore mandatory
Indicates the clinic or facility which originally issued the prescription.
Identifies where paper records are likely located for follow-up. This is marked as 'populated' because it won't always be known for 'inferred prescriptions.
Indicates the pharmacy to which the prescription has been directed or which has currently assumed responsibility for dispensing the prescription.
Prescription.facility

Allows prescriptions to be directed on the request of the patient or by legal requirement. Also allows indication of which pharmacy is the current 'custodian' of the prescription.

This should always be known or should have an explicit null flavor of 'NA' (non-assigned) or 'UNK' (paper prescription). Thus the association is 'populated'.

Allows prescriptions to be directed on the request of the patient or by legal requirement. Also allows indication of which pharmacy is the current 'custodian' of the prescription.

This should always be known or should have an explicit null flavor of 'NA' (non-assigned) or 'UNK' (paper prescription). Thus the association is 'populated'.
The date and time on which the dispense is expected to be picked up.
Allows a prescriber to indicate to the targeted pharmacy, when patient will be expecting to pick up the dispensed medication.
Indicates whether a dispenser to whom the prescription is targeted is a mandated or patient-preferred pharmacy.
Influences whether the prescription may be transferred to a service delivery location other than the targeted dispenser.
This is the detailed information about a medication dispense that has been performed on behalf of a patient.
A_BillablePharmacyDispense
Dispensing is an integral part of the overall medication process.

The Prescription Dispense Number is a globally unique number assigned to a dispense (single fill) by the EHR/DIS irrespective of the source of the dispense.

It is created by the EHR/DIS once the dispense has passed all edits and validation.

The Prescription Dispense Number is a globally unique number assigned to a dispense (single fill) by the EHR/DIS irrespective of the source of the dispense.

It is created by the EHR/DIS once the dispense has passed all edits and validation.
