Helps other providers to make appropriate decisions in their management of allergy or intolerance contraindications.

Attribute is mandatory because an allergy or intolerance record must be tagged as either 'confirmed' or 'suspected'.

Helps other providers to make appropriate decisions in their management of allergy or intolerance contraindications.

Attribute is mandatory because an allergy or intolerance record must be tagged as either 'confirmed' or 'suspected'.
Indicates the substance to which the patient is allergic
Critical for identifying the allergy or intolerance. Because it is not used for SNOMED, this element is optional.
Indicates the service delivery location where the allergy was recorded.

Indicates where records are likely kept for follow-up. May also be useful in understanding the context in which the allergy/intolerance was recorded. The location of entry should always be known, and is therefore mandatory.
Category of material or agent to which the patient was exposed.
Allows exposed materials or agents to be collectively referenced.
Indicates the type of agent that the patient was exposed to which caused the adverse reaction. This includes Drug, Food, Latex, Dust, etc.

Allows different kinds of reaction agents to be distinguished. Coding strength is set to CWE because the exposure agent type may not always be codified. The attribute is populated because there is little point in communicating about the exposure to an agent if it is not known what the agent is, however it may not always be coded.
This is a recording of a patient reaction that is believed to be associated with the allergy/intolerance.

Helps providers to distinguish between proper allergies and intolerances. Allows the provider recording the allergy to assign appropriate severity to the allergy. May give insight on how to mitigate an intolerance that is likely to be triggered by administering a substance. (E.g. If a given drug typically causes nausea in the patient, an additional medication may be co-prescribed to manage the nausea.)
An identifier assigned to the record of the adverse reaction.
Allows for direct referencing of an adverse reaction record which was previously recorded.
Indicates the type of diagnosis being captured.
Indicates that the observation is actually a diagnosis and is therefore mandatory. The datatype is CD to support SNOMED post-coordination.
If using SNOMED, this will contain the diagnosis. Otherwise it will be a fixed value of 'DX'.
Indicates if there there was an adverse reaction when the patient was exposed to the agent to which an allergy/intolerance has been recorded.

Allows providers to confirm or eliminate specific agents as being the cause for the allergy/intolerance. E.g. If a reaction is recorded for Tylenol 3, but no reaction is recorded for regular Tylenol or for coffee, this suggests that the likely cause of the allergy is Codeine.

The attribute is mandatory because it is essential to know whether the reaction occurred or not.

Allows providers to confirm or eliminate specific agents as being the cause for the allergy/intolerance. E.g. If a reaction is recorded for Tylenol 3, but no reaction is recorded for regular Tylenol or for coffee, this suggests that the likely cause of the allergy is Codeine.

The attribute is mandatory because it is essential to know whether the reaction occurred or not.
A free form description of the reaction.
B.4
Allows for flexibility in the recording and reporting of the reaction.
The date on which the reaction occurrence began.
Indicates when evidence of the condition first appeared. May also provide information on the duration of the reaction.
Specifies the kind of reaction, as experienced by the patient.
B.1

Ensures consistency in tracking and categorizing the reaction type. Helps ensure that only proper allergies are categorized as allergy. The attribute is optional because it will not be used for SNOMED. The attribute is CWE because not all possible types of reactions are expressible by coded values.
Identity of the provider who is taking responsibility for the actions of the author.
Allows for the trail of responsibility for the action.
This is a ranking/ an assertion of the seriouness of the diagnosed/reported medical condition.
Allows providers to determine appropriate managements for contraindications involving such medical conditions.
.
Indicates the gravity of the allergy, intolerance or reaction in terms of its actual or potential impact on the patient.
AllergyIntolerance.severity
Allows for sorting of allergy records. May influence whether contraindications must be managed. Because this concept is pre-coordinated with code for SNOMED, the association is optional.
Indicates the agent that is believed to have caused the adverse reaction.
Provides support for the agent identified as the allergen/intolerance source.
An indication of the severity of the reaction.
Allows providers to evaluate the significance of the allergy or intolerance. Because severity is communicated as part of the reaction code in SNOMED, this association is optional
Indicates the severity of the allergy/intolerance.

Useful for determining severity of an allergy/intolerance contraindication and the management of same. Because allergy severity is communicated as part of the code for SNOMED, this associaiton is optional.
Indicates the person suffering from the allergy/intolerance.
AllergyIntolerance.person
Ties the condition to a particular patient record, and is therefore mandatory.
Indicates the various comments that providers have recorded about this allergy/intolerance.

Improves communication between providers by allowing a mechanism to exchange un-coded free-form information.

This association is mandatory as it indicates one of presence or absence notes.

Improves communication between providers by allowing a mechanism to exchange un-coded free-form information.

This association is mandatory as it indicates one of presence or absence notes.
Indicates the various comments that providers have recorded about this allergy or intolerance record.
Improves communication between providers by allowing a mechanism to exchange un-coded free-form information.
Indicates a particular type of reaction experienced by the patient or testing performed on the patient which provides evidence for the existence (or non-existence) of the allergy/intolerance.
May help ascertain the severity of the condition, and provide direction for management. Also helps demonstrate the distinction between allergies and intolerances
Identifier of the Condition record to be retrieved. This can pertain to an allergy/intolerance or medical condition record.
Identifies the specific condition record to retrieve and is therefore mandatory.
Defines the set of parameters that may be used to filter the query response
Root class for query definition
Indicates the date on which the patient was born.
Used to confirm the identity of the patient for the query and is therefore mandatory.
Indicates the gender (sex) of the patient.
Used to confirm the identity of the patient for the query and is therefore mandatory.
Identifier of the patient who is the subject of the condition history query. Filter the result set to include only those records pertaining to the patient with this Id.
Allows filtering of result set by patient Id. This is a mandatory field because a patient must be specified for the query to be valid

The name of the patient who is the subject of the condition history query.

Filter the result set to include only those records pertaining to the patient with this name.

The name of the patient who is the subject of the condition history query.

Filter the result set to include only those records pertaining to the patient with this name.
Allows filtering of result set by patient name. This is a mandatory field because a patient name must match the patient Id for the query to be valid.
A specific material or agent that to which the patient was exposed. Examples are: Codein (Drug), Peanut (Food), etc.
Allows the provider to zero in on specific culprits for the adverse reaction.
Indicates the specific allergy test that supports the recording of the allergy/intolerance.
Provides evidence for recording the allergy/intolerance.
An identifier for a specific instance of an allergy/intolerance test.
Allows an allergy/intolerance test record to be directly referenced.
A coded value denoting the type of allergy test conducted.
Allows different kinds of allergy/intolerance tests to be distinguishable and is therefore mandatory. It uses the CD type to support SNOMED post-coordination.
The date on which the allergy test was performed.
Allows providers to evaluate the currency of the test.
A code indicating result of the allergy test.

Allows other providers to evaluate the test. There is no point in associating an allergy test with unknown results with an allergy or intolerance however the element is optional because this information may be post-coordinated in the 'code' attribute using SNOMED.
Identifies the provider who reported the allergy or intolerance.

Identifies responsibility for accuracy and relevance of the information. This association reflects primary responsibility, and is therefore mandatory.
The date and time on which the allergy/intolerance record was created.
Identifies timing of allergy/intolerance for sorting and for audit purposes. Attribute is populated because the source of the data may not be through the 'record common observation' interaction.
Identity of the health service provider responsible for the change in the allergy/intolerance status.

In an EHR integrated health services environment, it is important that other providers are able to query who is responsible for a given change. Also used by applications for auditing and sorting. The attribute is mandatory because the responsible provider should always be known.
The date on which the change was made.

Gives other providers the frame of reference in evaluating any post-change issues with the allergy. Also used for sorting and audit purposes. Time of change is always known and thus the attribute is mandatory.
This is a recording of a patient reaction that is believed to be associated with the allergy/intolerance.

Helps providers to distinguish between proper allergies and intolerances. Allows the provider recording the allergy to assign appropriate severity to the allergy. May give insight on how to mitigate an intolerance that is likely to be triggered by administering a substance. (E.g. If a given drug typically causes nausea in the patient, an additional medication may be co-prescribed to manage the nausea.)

Indicates the specific substance involved in the incidence that caused the reaction.
Identification of offending substance is needed for management of the reaction.
This records the history of changes that have been made to the allergy/intolerance, including why the changes were made, who made them and when.
Provides a record of a patient's allergy changes, providing deeper clinical understanding, particularly of past clinical decisions.
Identifies what kind of change occurred. Allergy/Intolerance change types are Revise, Reactivate and Complete.
This attribute is mandatory to ensure that change types are distinguishable.
The date on which the various changes of an allergy/intolerance become valid and applicable.
Allows applications to sort and filter by time. The date on which a change is effective should always be known and thus is mandatory.
Denotes the reason the the allergy/intolerance was changed.
Ensures consistent terminology in capturing and interpreting reasons for change. Allows CWE because not all reasons will correspond to a pre-defined code.

A code indicating result of the allergy test.

Allows other providers to evaluate the test. There is no point in associating an allergy test with unknown results with an allergy or intolerance however the element is optional because this information may be post-coordinated in the 'code' attribute using SNOMED.
This is a recording of a patient reaction that is believed to be associated with the allergy/intolerance.

Helps providers to distinguish between proper allergies and intolerances. Allows the provider recording the allergy to assign appropriate severity to the allergy. May give insight on how to mitigate an intolerance that is likely to be triggered by administering a substance. (E.g. If a given drug typically causes nausea in the patient, an additional medication may be co-prescribed to manage the nausea.)
Indicates the type of assessment being made

Communicates the relatedness assessment of the exposure to the reaction and is therefore mandatory. For SNOMED this will communicate the full assessment. It is expressed as a CD to allow for SNOMED post-coordination.
For SNOMED this will include the actual assessment. For non-SNOMED, this should be fixed to RXNASSES.
Indicates whether the reaction is deemed to be related to the exposure.
Creates the link between the exposure and the reaction. Because the details of the assessment will be communicated in the 'code' attribute for SNOMED, this element is optional.
This attribute will not be populated if using SNOMED. Otherwise it should have a fixed value of "RELATED".
Indicates the specific substance involved in the incidence that caused the reaction.
Identification of offending substance is needed for management of the reaction.

Incidence of the patient's exposure to (or contact with) with some material that might have caused the adverse reaction.

Examples of exposures include: Administering a substance (drug, food, etc) to the patient, Patient coming into contact with an environmental material, etc.

Incidence of the patient's exposure to (or contact with) with some material that might have caused the adverse reaction.

Examples of exposures include: Administering a substance (drug, food, etc) to the patient, Patient coming into contact with an environmental material, etc.
Communicates the cause of the adverse reaction.
Identifier of the exposure event that caused the adverse reaction. This could be an identifier for a prescription, immunization, or other active medication record.
Allows for drilling down to retrieve further information about the exposure
The method by which the patient was exposed to the substance.
Helps evaluate the cause of the reaction.

Indicates where the information that led to the recording of this information came from. The possible 3 sources of the information are: the patient, the patient's representative or a health-care provider.
The original source of the information can be important in evaluating its accuracy and importance.
The date on which the allergy/intolerance was reported.
Allows for establishment of timelines between onset date, reported date and recorded date, and is therefore mandatory.
A record of a patient's allergy or intolerance.
Necessary component of a person's overall medication and clinical profile. Helps with drug contraindication checking.
Unique identifier for an allergy/intolerance record.
Indicates the allergy or intolerance record to be updated and is therefore mandatory.
A coded value denoting whether the record pertains to an intolerance or a true allergy. (Allergies result from immunologic reactions. Intolerances do not.)

Allows for the separation of allergy and intolerance records. The type of condition is critical to understanding the record and is therefore mandatory. It is expressed as a CD to allow for SNOMED post-coordination.
An indication that the allergy/intolerance has been refuted. I.e. A clinician has positively determined that the patient does not suffer from a particular allergy or intolerance.
Allows providers to refute a previously confirmed or suspected allergy. Because it is essential to know whether the allergy or intolerance is being refuted or affirmed, this attribute is mandatory.
A coded value that indicates whether an allergy/intolerance is 'ACTIVE' or 'COMPLETE' (indicating no longer active).
Allows providers to evaluate the relevance of a recorded allergy/intolerance. The status has a default value of 'ACTIVE' and is therefore mandatory.
System must default the status to 'ACTIVE'.
The date on which the recorded allergy is considered active.
Allows providers to evaluate the period of relevance for the allergy/intolerance record.

Denotes access restriction placed on the allergy or intolerance record. Methods for accessing masked allergy records will be governed by each jurisdiction (e.g. court orders, shared secret/consent, etc.). The default confidentiality level is 'NORMAL'.

Provides support for additional confidentiality constraint to reflect the wishes of the patient.

The attribute is optional because not all systems will support masking.

Provides support for additional confidentiality constraint to reflect the wishes of the patient.

The attribute is optional because not all systems will support masking.

An indication of the level of confidence/surety placed in the recorded information.

The two valid codes are:

- U (stated with uncertainty) -Specifies that the author of the act affirms the uncertainty of the act statement. In other words, they know that parts of the act statement are not certain or are inferred. An example of this is an inferred prescription where some order data is inferred from a supply event (i.e. dispense).

- N (stated with no assertion of uncertainty) - Specifies that the act statement is made without any explicit expression of certainty/uncertainty. This is the normal statement, meaning that it may not be free of errors and uncertainty may still exist. In healthcare, N is believed to express certainty to the strength possible.

An allergy or intolerance record is always used in drug contraindication checking whether the record is U or N.

An indication of the level of confidence/surety placed in the recorded information.

- U (stated with uncertainty) -Specifies that the author of the act affirms the uncertainty of the act statement. Helps other providers to make appropriate decisions in their management of allergy or intolerance contraindications.

Attribute is mandatory because an allergy or intolerance record must be tagged as either 'confirmed' or 'suspected'.

Helps other providers to make appropriate decisions in their management of allergy or intolerance contraindications.

Attribute is mandatory because an allergy or intolerance record must be tagged as either 'confirmed' or 'suspected'.
Category of material or agent to which the patient was exposed.
Allows exposed materials or agents to be collectively referenced.
Indicates the type of agent that the patient was exposed to which caused the adverse reaction. This includes Drug, Food, Latex, Dust, etc.

Allows different kinds of reaction agents to be distinguished. Coding strength is set to CWE because the exposure agent type may not always be codified. The attribute is populated because there is little point in communicating about the exposure to an agent if it is not known what the agent is, however it may not always be coded.
An identifier assigned to the record of the adverse reaction.
Allows for direct referencing of an adverse reaction record which was previously recorded.
Indicates the type of diagnosis being captured.
Indicates that the observation is actually a diagnosis and is therefore mandatory. The datatype is CD to support SNOMED post-coordination.
If using SNOMED, this will contain the diagnosis. Otherwise it will be a fixed value of 'DX'.
Indicates that there was no adverse reaction when the patient was exposed to the agent to which an allergy/intolerance has been recorded.

Allows providers to confirm or eliminate specific agents as being the cause for the allergy/intolerance. E.g. If a reaction is recorded for Tylenol 3, but no reaction is recorded for regular Tylenol or for coffee, this suggests that the likely cause of the allergy is Codeine.

Because it is essential to know whether the reaction occurred or not, this attribute is mandatory.

Allows providers to confirm or eliminate specific agents as being the cause for the allergy/intolerance. E.g. If a reaction is recorded for Tylenol 3, but no reaction is recorded for regular Tylenol or for coffee, this suggests that the likely cause of the allergy is Codeine.

Because it is essential to know whether the reaction occurred or not, this attribute is mandatory.
A free form description of the reaction.
B.4
Allows for flexibility in the recording and reporting of the reaction.
The date on which the reaction occurrence began.
Indicates when evidence of the condition first appeared. May also provide information on the duration of the reaction.
Specifies the kind of reaction, as experienced by the patient.
B.1

Ensures consistency in tracking and categorizing the reaction type. Helps ensure that only proper allergies are categorized as allergy. The attribute is optional because it will not be used for SNOMED. The attribute is CWE because not all possible types of reactions are expressible by coded values.
This is a ranking/ an assertion of the seriouness of the diagnosed/reported medical condition.
Allows providers to determine appropriate managements for contraindications involving such medical conditions.
.
Indicates the gravity of the allergy, intolerance or reaction in terms of its actual or potential impact on the patient.
AllergyIntolerance.severity

Allows for sorting of allergy records. May influence whether contraindications must be managed.

Because SNOMED pre-coordinates severity into code, this association is optional

Allows for sorting of allergy records. May influence whether contraindications must be managed.

Because SNOMED pre-coordinates severity into code, this association is optional
Indicates the agent that is believed to have caused the adverse reaction.
Provides support for the agent identified as the allergen/intolerance source.
An indication of the severity of the reaction.
Allows providers to evaluate the significance of the allergy or intolerance. Because severity is pre-coordinated into code when using SNOMED, this association is optional.
Indicates the severity of the allergy/intolerance.
Useful for determining severity of an allergy/intolerance contraindication and the management of same. Because severity is pre-coordinated into code when using SNOMED, this association is optional.
Identifies the person suffering from the allergy/intolerance.
AllergyIntolerance.person
Ties the condition to a particular patient record, and is therefore mandatory.
Indicates a particular type of reaction experienced by the patient or testing performed on the patient which provides evidence for the existence (or non-existence) of the allergy/intolerance.
May help ascertain the severity of the condition, and provide direction for management. Also helps demonstrate the distinction between allergies and intolerances
